4f8e5b82e80eb0e4f0091588 3 7----Bio----#text.P.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	verif:1 particularli:1 illinoi:2 phd:2 test:1 award:2 occupi:1 electr:2 industri:1 academia:1 faculti:1 urbana:1 stanford:1 regent:1 center:1 supervis:1 student:1 univers:3 interest:1 texa:1 recipi:1 dissert:1 elect:1 famili:1 hold:1 jacob:1 director:1 cite:1 ieee:2 formal:1 professor:1 comput:4 emanuel:1 fellow:2 posit:1 vlsi:1 senior:1 austin:1 accomplish:1 abraham:1 paper:1 engin:4 isi:1 cockrel:1 extens:1 best:1 publish:1 scienc:1 toler:1 includ:2 acm:1 receiv:2 list:1 fault:1 research:3 chair:1 proud:1 design:1 world:1 pior:1	||	Jacob A. Abraham is Professor of Electrical and Computer Engineering at the University of Texas at Austin. He is also the director of the Computer Engineering Research Center and holds a Cockrell Family Regents Chair in Engineering. He received his Ph.D. in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science from Stanford University in 1974. From 1975 to 1988 he was on the faculty of the University of Illinois, Urbana, Illinois. His research interests include VLSI design and test, formal verification, and fault-tolerant computing. He has published extensively, has received many "best paper" awards, and is included in the ISI list of the most cited researchers in the world. He has supervised more than 80 Ph.D. dissertations, and is particularly proud of the accomplishments of his students, many of whom occupy senior positions in academia and industry. He has been elected Fellow of the IEEE as well as Fellow of the ACM, and is the recipient of the 2005 IEEE Emanuel R. Piore Award.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Electrical and Computer Engineering; University of Texas; Computer Engineering Research Center; Computer Science; Stanford University; University of Illinois; VLSI; ISI; 	PERSON: Jacob A. 4f8e5b82e80eb0e4c1091588 2 23----Bio----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	phd:1 dollimor:1 servic:1 distribut:6 middlewar:4 doctor:1 confer:2 univers:2 interest:1 relat:1 train:1 chief:1 usenix:1 director:1 trom:1 digit:1 editor:1 system:6 appli:1 co:2 environment:1 program:1 pc:1 professor:2 economi:1 highwir:1 comput:2 commun:1 internet:1 committe:1 adjunct:1 cross:1 perspect:1 centr:1 concept:1 gordon:1 model:1 seri:1 paper:1 engin:1 adapt:2 applic:2 journal:1 disciplinari:1 author:1 driven:1 current:1 ifip:1 contemporari:1 publish:2 innov:1 major:1 norwai:1 scienc:1 includ:3 acm:1 lancast:1 edit:1 highli:1 blair:2 research:1 technolog:1 coulouri:1 techniqu:1 field:1 chair:1 school:1 kindberg:1 architectur:1 take:1 steer:1 book:1 intern:1 cloud:1 success:1 design:1 reflect:1	||	Gordon Blair is a Professor of Distributed Systems in the School of Computing and Communications at Lancaster University and is also an Adjunct Professor at the University of Troms in Norway. He has published over 280 papers in his field and is on the PCs of many major international conferences in middleware and distributed systems. He is also chair of the steering committee of the ACM/ IFIP/ Usenix Middleware series of conferences. His current research interests include distributed systems architecture, middleware (including reflective and adaptive middleware), model-driven engineering techniques applied to adaptive distributed systems, and the applicability of contemporary distributed systems technologies (including cloud computing) to environmental science. He is co-author of the highly successful book Distributed Systems: Concepts and Design by Coulouris, Dollimore, Kindberg and Blair with the 5th edition published in 2011. He is also Director of the HighWire Centre for Doctoral Training, a PhD programe taking a cross-disciplinary perspective on innovation as it relates to the digital economy, and is co-editor in chief of Springer's Journal of Internet Services and Applications.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: School of Computing and Communications; Lancaster University; University of Troms; Usenix Middleware; Journal of Internet Services; 	PERSON: Gordon Blair; Coulouris; Dollimore; Kindberg; Blair; Springer; 	DATE: 2011; 	LOCATION: Norway; 	NOUN: Gordon Blair; Professor; Systems; School; Computing; Communications; Lancaster University; Adjunct Professor; University; Troms; Norway; papers; field; PCs; conferences; middleware; systems; chair; committee; ACM; IFIP; Usenix Middleware series; conferences; research interests; systems architecture; middleware; middleware; engineering techniques; systems; applicability; systems technologies; cloud computing; science; co-author; book; Systems; Concepts; Design; Coulouris; Dollimore; Kindberg; Blair; edition; Director; HighWire Centre; Doctoral Training; PhD programe; perspective; innovation; economy; co-editor; chief; Springer; Journal; Internet Services; Applications; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

He has published eight books, over fifty journal articles and over eighty conference presentations and book chapters. He is well known for his research in computer-supported system design and modeling, system failures and risk assessment, computer-supported cooperative work and the diffusion of complex technologies. He is currently researching the development and management of digital services and the evolution of virtual communities. Kalle is also active in the international information systems community. He has served in leadership positions for several academic organizations, conferences and journals. 5076ad4ccc52b0e40519b167 1 3----Research----#text.P.DIV.ARTICLE.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	femal:1 face:8 person:3 can:2 gener:1 etc:1 identifi:1 approxim:1 object:1 express:1 build:1 arbitrari:1 tree:1 immedi:1 find:1 look:1 detect:3 locat:2 ignor:1 vision:1 task:1 rich:1 male:1 number:1 regard:1 imag:2 technolog:1 human:2 size:2 digit:1 inform:1 bodi:1 facial:2 determin:1 featur:1 comput:1 sourc:1 known:1 local:2 case:1 ag:1	||	Face detection is a computer-vision technology that determines the location and size of a human face in an arbitrary (digital) image. The facial features in the image are detected, and any other objects like trees, buildings, bodies, etc. are ignored. The human face is a rich source of information by looking at the person s face, we can immediately identify whether the person is male or female, the person s approximate age, facial expression, and so on. Face detection can be regarded as a more general case of face localization. In face localization, the task is to find the locations and sizes of a known number of faces.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: Face detection; technology; location; size; face; image; features; image; objects; trees; buildings; bodies; face; source; information; person; face; person; person; age; expression; Face detection; case; face localization; face localization; task; locations; sizes; number; faces; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##true@@false$$

4f8e5b82e80eb0e491091588 1 2----Research----#text.P.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.DIV.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.BODY.HTML.#document	total:1 need:1 simpl:1 paradigm:2 servic:1 maintain:1 distribut:4 neighbor:1 scalabl:1 corrupt:1 sensor:1 open:1 essenti:1 relat:1 action:1 longer:1 coordin:1 limit:1 transient:1 global:4 involv:1 cost:1 provid:1 invari:1 node:3 system:4 discuss:1 due:1 entir:1 small:1 might:1 defin:1 can:1 set:1 knowledg:3 data:1 state:1 self:2 object:1 network:6 introduc:1 hoc:1 algorithm:2 wireless:1 graph:1 immedi:1 built:1 toler:1 look:1 protocol:1 fraction:1 domin:1 failur:1 fundament:1 track:1 particip:2 predic:1 problem:1 us:1 fault:1 storag:1 stabil:2 achiev:1 optimist:1 effect:1 take:1 exampl:1 safeguard:1 base:1 ad:1 local:4 rel:1 design:2 keep:1 yet:1	||	Many essential fundamental services for networked distributed systems (ad hoc, wireless or sensor) involve maintaining a global predicate over the entire network (defined by some invariance relation on the global state of the network) by using local knowledge at each of the participating nodes. The participating nodes can no longer keep track of even a small fraction of the knowledge about the global network due to limited storage. We need a new paradigm of localized distributed algorithms, where a node takes simple actions based on local knowledge of only its immediate neighbors and yet the system achieves a global objective. Self-stabilization is a relatively new paradigm for designing such localized distributed algorithms for networks; it is an optimistic way of looking at system fault tolerance and scalable coordination; it provides a cost effective built-in safeguard against transient failures that might corrupt data in a distributed system. We introduce self-stabilizing protocol design with the example of a total dominating set in a network graph and discuss some open problems.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: services; systems; ad; sensor; predicate; network; invariance relation; state; network; knowledge; nodes; nodes; track; fraction; knowledge; network; storage; paradigm; algorithms; node; actions; knowledge; neighbors; system; objective; Self-stabilization; paradigm; algorithms; networks; way; system fault tolerance; coordination; cost; failures; data; system; protocol design; example; network graph; problems; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##true@@false$$
4f8e5b82e80eb0e491091588 1 3----Bio----#text.B.P.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.DIV.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.BODY.HTML.#document	biographi:1 brief:1	||	Brief Biography	##true@@false$$		||	NOUN: Biography; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##true@@false$$
4f8e5b82e80eb0e491091588 1 4----Bio----#text.P.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.DIV.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.BODY.HTML.#document	mathematik:1 illinoi:2 depart:1 state:1 germani:1 faculti:1 gesselschaft:1 southern:1 fuer:1 clemson:1 univers:5 electron:1 carbondal:1 collin:1 august:1 india:2 serv:1 franc:1 ft:1 decemb:1 institut:2 bonn:1 scienc:1 previous:1 physic:1 manag:1 colorado:2 indian:2 receiv:1 compiegn:1 technolog:1 pradip:1 statist:1 degre:1 chair:1 und:1 calcutta:4 carolina:1 professor:1 radio:1 south:1 comput:1 srimani:1 datenverarbeitung:1 ph:1 west:1	||	Pradip K Srimani	##false@@true$$	is a professor computer science at Clemson University, South Carolina (he was department chair between August 2000 and December 2006). He had previously served the faculty of Indian Statistical Institute, Calcutta, Gesselschaft fuer Mathematik und Datenverarbeitung, Bonn, West Germany, Indian Institute of Management, Calcutta, India, Southern Illinois University, Carbondale, Illinois, Colorado State University in Ft. Before coming to Brown in 1990, he spent four years at the European Computer-Industry Research Center (ECRC), where he was the main designer and implementor of the CHIP programming system, the foundation of all modern constraint programming systems. During the last 15 years, he developed a number of influential systems, including the	##false@@false$$	Numerica	##false@@true$$	system for global optimization, the optimization programming language	##false@@false$$	OPL	##false@@true$$	, and the programming language	##false@@false$$	Comet	##false@@true$$	which supports both constraint-based local search and constraint programming. Most of these systems are described in books published by the MIT Press and have been licensed to industry. He also implemented the generic abstract interpretation system GAIA.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Brown University; European Computer-Industry Research Center; ECRC; Numerica; OPL; Comet; MIT; 	PERSON: Pascal Van Hentenryck; Brown; 	DATE: 1990; 	NOUN: Pascal Van Hentenryck; professor; computer science; Brown University; director; optimization laboratory; Brown; years; Computer-Industry Research Center; ECRC; designer; implementor; CHIP programming system; foundation; constraint programming systems; years; number; systems; Numerica system; optimization; optimization programming language OPL; programming language Comet; search; constraint programming; systems; books; MIT Press; industry; interpretation system GAIA; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##true@@true$$

4f8e5b50e80eb0e410ed1488 2 16----Research----#text.P.SPAN.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	understand:3 decreas:1 gener:1 servic:4 cours:2 seamless:1 appeal:1 congest:1 multipl:1 numer:1 random:2 qualiti:2 suggest:1 provid:4 present:1 ieee:1 traffic:1 advanc:1 provis:1 review:1 upon:1 increas:1 next:1 engin:4 constraint:1 issu:1 applic:2 comprehens:1 scienc:1 addit:2 us:1 access:1 stabil:1 framework:1 research:2 field:1 red:1 overview:1 exampl:1 invalu:1 design:1 particularli:1 undertak:1 integr:1 tool:3 promis:1 good:1 perform:2 show:1 electr:1 earli:1 impact:1 kei:1 requir:1 student:2 control:1 learn:1 tune:1 playback:1 comput:1 case:1 internet:4 characterist:1 furthermor:1 model:1 network:7 introduc:1 author:1 wireless:9 chapter:1 resourc:1 order:1 read:1 implement:2 graduat:1 question:1 fine:1 analyt:2 detect:1 postgradu:1 protocol:2 futur:1 qo:3 includ:1 paramet:1 aimd:2 addition:1 multimedia:7 effect:1 architectur:1 address:1 book:4 featur:2 investig:1 measur:1 studi:2 illustr:1 growth:1	||	Learn how to provide seamless, high quality multimedia for the wireless Internet This book introduces the promising protocols for multimedia services and presents the analytical frameworks for measuring their performance in wireless networks. Furthermore, the book shows how to fine-tune the parameters for Quality of Service (QoS) provisioning in order to illustrate the effect that QoS has upon the stability, integrity and growth of next generation wireless Internet. In addition, the authors provide the tools required to implement this understanding. These tools are particularly useful for design and engineering network architecture and protocols for future wireless Internet. Additionally, the book provides a good overview of wireless networks, while also appealing to network researchers and engineers. Key Features : Provides a comprehensive and analytical understanding of the performance of multimedia services in wireless Internet, and the tools to implement such an understanding Addresses issues such as IEEE 802.11, AIMD/RED (Additive Increase-Multiplicative Decrease/ Random Early Detection), multimedia traffic models, congestion control and random access networks Investigates the impact of wireless characteristics on QoS constraint multimedia applications Includes a case study on AIMD for multimedia playback applications Features numerous examples, suggested reading and review questions for each chapter This book is an invaluable resource for postgraduate students undertaking courses in wireless networks and multimedia services, students studying advanced graduate courses in electrical engineering and computer science, and researchers and engineers in the field of wireless networks.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Quality of Service; 	NOUN: quality multimedia; Internet; book; protocols; multimedia services; frameworks; performance; networks; book; parameters; Quality; Service; QoS; order; effect; QoS; stability; integrity; growth; generation; Internet; addition; authors; tools; understanding; tools; design; engineering network architecture; protocols; Internet; book; overview; networks; network researchers; engineers; Key; understanding; performance; multimedia services; Internet; tools; understanding; issues; IEEE; AIMD\/RED; Decrease; Random Early Detection; multimedia; models; congestion control; access networks; impact; characteristics; QoS constraint multimedia applications; case study; AIMD; multimedia playback applications; examples; reading; review questions; chapter; book; resource; students; courses; networks; multimedia services; students; graduate courses; engineering; computer science; researchers; engineers; field; networks; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

4f8e5b50e80eb0e410ed1488 1 7----Bio----#text.SPAN.P.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	phd:1 hall:1 award:1 renam:1 electr:4 univers:3 interest:1 munic:1 academi:1 infocom:1 commu:1 recipi:1 work:1 text:1 million:1 informa:1 canada:2 mobil:1 mark:1 wide:1 director:2 prentic:1 deliveri:1 monei:1 degre:1 system:1 editor:3 co:1 ieee:3 transact:2 program:1 canadian:2 professor:1 nicat:1 distinguish:1 commun:4 comput:2 fellow:2 provis:1 committe:1 mcmaster:1 upon:1 cross:1 chairman:2 centr:2 depart:4 univeristi:1 engin:5 net:1 network:4 waterloo:3 journal:2 author:1 wireless:5 resourc:1 area:1 associ:1 tion:1 societi:1 telecom:1 current:1 serv:2 jon:1 publish:1 end:2 member:1 telecommun:1 technic:1 qo:1 acm:2 seed:1 manag:2 establish:1 layer:1 receiv:1 join:1 donat:1 research:2 inter:1 focu:1 emeritu:1 steer:1 ericsson:1 design:1 found:1	||	Jon W. Mark	##true@@false$$	is a Distinguished Professor Emeritus and the Director of the Centre for Wireless Communications, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Waterloo. Upon receiving the Ph.D. degree in electrical engineering from McMaster University, he joined the Department of Electrical Engineering (renamed the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering in 1989), University of Waterloo, Canada, in 1970. He served as the department Chairman from 1984 to 1990. With a 1 million donation from Ericsson Canada as seed money, he established the Centre for Wireless Commu- nications at the Univeristy of Waterloo in 1996, and has since been serving as the founding Director. His current research interests are in wireless communications and net- working, with a focus on resource management, mobility management, cross-layer design, and end-to-end informa- tion delivery with QoS provisioning. A Fellow of the IEEE and a Fellow of the Canadian Academy of Engineering, he is the recipient of the 2000 Canadian Award in Telecom- munications Research. He co-authored the text, Wireless Communications and Networking, published by Prentice- Hall in 2003. He was the Editor for Wide Area Networks of the IEEE Transactions on Communications from 1983 to 1989, the Technical Program Chairman of Infocom'89, a member of the Inter-Society Steering Committee of the IEEE/ACM Transactions on Networking from 1992 to 2003, an Editor of the ACM journal of Wireless Networks from 1993 to 2004, and an Associate Editor of the journal of Telecommunication Systems from 1994 to 2004.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Centre for Wireless Communications; Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering; University of Waterloo; McMaster University; Department of Electrical Engineering; Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering; University of Waterloo; Ericsson Canada; Centre for Wireless Commu; Univeristy of Waterloo; Canadian Academy of Engineering; 2000 Canadian Award in Telecom; Wireless Communications and Networking; Prentice; Infocom; Inter-Society Steering Committee of the IEEE\/ACM Transactions; Wireless Networks; Telecommunication Systems; 	PERSON: Jon W. Mark; 	DATE: 1989; 1970; 1984; 1990; 1996; 2003; 1983; 1989; 1992; 2003; 1993; 2004; 1994; 2004; 	LOCATION: Canada; 	NOUN: Jon W. The project, in collaboration with OCAD University, Empress Software and The Globe and Mail, also seeks to develop new tools for media users to shape emotional content and respond to others.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: OCAD University; Empress Software; The Globe; 	PERSON: Grant; Cercone; 	NOUN: part; Strategic Project Grant; identification; visualization; media content; form text; Relationships; information influence; diversity; Cercone; research team; sentiment; content; texts; tools; emotions; media texts; project; collaboration; OCAD University; Empress Software; Globe; Mail; tools; media users; content; others; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

4f8e5b51e80eb0e4c8ed1488 1 9----Bio----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	acquir:1 phd:1 advisori:2 award:1 visit:1 scientist:1 bs:1 electr:1 brazilian:2 doctor:1 confer:2 jim:1 inc:1 search:1 univers:3 interest:1 relat:1 fund:1 head:1 founder:1 topic:1 dissert:1 compani:1 california:1 hold:1 feder:2 alberto:1 board:1 nation:1 databas:3 digit:2 inform:2 degre:3 system:1 co:2 program:2 palo:1 professor:1 comput:3 googl:1 committe:4 gerai:2 agenc:1 akwan:1 model:1 hp:1 depart:1 paper:1 mina:2 data:1 engin:1 lab:1 journal:1 author:1 prof:2 sigmod:2 full:1 current:2 serv:2 east:1 scienc:2 alto:1 msc:1 grai:1 member:2 uk:1 includ:1 acm:1 manag:1 librari:2 web:3 conceptu:1 join:1 technolog:2 research:3 sever:2 chair:1 brazil:1 laender:3 intern:1 refere:1 anglia:1 group:1 design:1	||	Alberto H. F. Laender holds a BS degree in Electrical Engineering and an MSc degree in Computer Science, both from the Federal University of Minas Gerais, Brazil, and a PhD degree in Computing from the University of East Anglia, UK. He joined the Computer Science Department at the Federal University of Minas Gerais in 1975, where he is currently a Full Professor and the head of the Database Research Group. In 1997, he was a Visiting Scientist at HP Labs in Palo Alto, California. He has served on the advisory committee of several Brazilian research funding agencies and is currently a member of the ACM SIGMOD Advisory Board and the SIGMOD Jim Gray Doctoral Dissertation Award Committee. Prof. Laender has also served as a program committee co-chair, as well as a program committee member, for several national and international conferences on databases, digital libraries and Web-related topics. He is the author of more than 100 refereed journal and conference papers, and was one of the co-founders of Akwan Information Technologies, a Brazilian search technology company acquired by Google Inc. in 2005. Prof. Laender s research interests include conceptual modeling and database design, web data management, web information systems, and digital libraries.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: MSc; Computer Science; Federal University of Minas Gerais; Computer Science Department; Federal University of Minas Gerais; Database Research Group; HP Labs; ACM SIGMOD Advisory Board; SIGMOD Jim Gray Doctoral Dissertation Award Committee; Akwan Information Technologies; Google Inc.; 	PERSON: Alberto H. F. Laender; 	DATE: 1975; 1997; 2005; 	LOCATION: Brazil; University of East Anglia; UK; Palo Alto; California; 	NOUN: Alberto H. F. 4f8e5b51e80eb0e4b0ed1488 2 7----Research----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	detail:1 vehicl:1 etc:2 intellig:3 besid:1 diffus:1 stochast:1 particl:2 given:1 scheme:1 search:1 social:2 bf:1 varieti:1 ant:2 pso:1 control:1 bee:2 coloni:3 sd:1 si:2 system:3 appli:1 popular:1 comput:1 forag:1 review:1 collect:1 artifici:1 cat:1 convent:1 can:2 behavior:2 typic:1 engin:1 self:1 inde:1 applic:1 network:1 algorithm:2 swarm:7 scienc:1 talk:1 telecommun:1 includ:1 optim:5 robot:2 problem:2 us:2 field:2 unman:1 overview:1 organ:1 experi:1 predict:1 bacteria:1 ac:2 base:1 enhanc:1	||	Swarm intelligence (SI) is based on collective behavior of self-organized systems. Typical swarm intelligence schemes include particle swarm optimization (PSO), ant colony system (ACS), stochastic diffusion search (SDS), bacteria foraging (BF), the bees algorithm, swarm robotics, etc. Besides the applications to conventional optimization problems, SI can be used in controlling robots and unmanned vehicles, predicting social behaviors, enhancing the telecommunication and computer networks, etc. Indeed, the use of swarm optimization can be applied to a variety of fields in engineering and social sciences. This talk reviews some popular algorithms in the field of swarm intelligence for problems of optimization. The detail overview and experiments of Particle and Cat Swarm Optimization, Ant Colony System (ACS) and Artificial Bee Colony are given.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: Swarm intelligence; SI; behavior; systems; swarm intelligence schemes; particle swarm optimization; PSO; colony system; ACS; diffusion search; SDS; bacteria; BF; bees algorithm; swarm robotics; applications; optimization problems; SI; robots; vehicles; behaviors; telecommunication; computer networks; use; swarm optimization; variety; fields; engineering; sciences; talk; algorithms; field; swarm intelligence; problems; optimization; detail overview; experiments; Particle; Cat Swarm Optimization; Ant Colony System; ACS; Artificial Bee Colony; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

S. degree in Electronic Engineering from the National Taiwan University of Science and Technology in 1986, the M. S. degree in Communication Engineering from the National Chiao Tung University, Taiwan in 1988, and the Ph.D. degree in Electrical Engineering from the University of Edinburgh, U.K. in 1996. Currently, he is a Professor in the Department of Electronic Engineering, National Kaohsiung University of Applied Sciences, Taiwan. He is also invited to be the Doctoral advisor both in University of South Australia and Harbin Institute of Technology. He jointed the editorial board of International Journal of Innovative Computing, Information and Control, LNCS Transactions on Data Hiding and Multimedia Security, International Journal of Hybrid Intelligent System, Journal of Information Assurance and Security, International Journal of Computer Sciences and Engineering System, Journal of Computers, International Journal of Digital Crime and Forensics, ICIC Express Letters, and Computational Intelligence and Its Applications Book Series (IGI Publishing). His current research interests include soft computing, information security and signal processing.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: National Taiwan University of Science and Technology; National Chiao Tung University; University of Edinburgh; Department of Electronic Engineering; National Kaohsiung University of Applied Sciences; University of South Australia; Harbin Institute of Technology; International Journal of Innovative Computing; Information and Control; International Journal of Hybrid Intelligent System; Journal of Information Assurance and Security; International Journal of Computer Sciences; Journal of Computers; International Journal of Digital Crime and Forensics; ICIC Express Letters; Computational Intelligence; 	DATE: 1986; 1988; 1996; 	LOCATION: Taiwan; U.K.; Taiwan; 	NOUN: Jeng-Shyang Pan; B. 4f8e5b50e80eb0e498ec1488 0 26----Bio----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	oregon:2 illinoi:2 phd:1 fulbright:2 award:4 visit:1 perform:1 scientist:1 bs:1 foundat:1 faculti:1 urbana:1 supercomput:1 center:1 allen:1 univers:5 hewlett:1 year:1 work:1 california:2 cedar:1 unvers:1 nation:1 angel:1 degre:1 inform:1 project:1 palo:1 nsf:1 professor:3 comput:2 austria:1 senior:2 lo:1 alexand:2 depart:1 engin:1 packard:1 champaign:1 maloni:6 vienna:1 von:2 full:1 prestigi:1 leader:1 promot:1 develop:1 scienc:2 alto:1 dr:3 netherland:1 softwar:1 degress:1 resid:1 ms:1 us:1 receiv:2 evalu:1 join:1 young:1 research:4 spend:1 octob:1 laboratori:1 investig:1 humboldt:2 utrecht:1 multiprocessor:1 scholar:2 respect:1	||	Dr. Allen D. Malony is a Professor in the Department of Computer and Information Science at the Unversity of Oregon. Malony received the B.S. and M.S. degress in Computer Science from the University of California, Los Angeles in 1980 and 1982, respectively. He received the Ph.D. degree from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign in October 1990. From 1981 to 1985, Malony worked at Hewlett-Packard Laboratories in Palo Alto, California. From 1986 to 1991, he was a Senior Software Engineer at the University of Illinois Center for Supercomputing Research and Development, where he was the leader of the performance evaluation project for the Cedar multiprocessor. In 1991, Malony joined the faculty at Oregon, spending his first year as a Fulbright Research Scholar and visiting Professor at Utrecht University in The Netherlands. Dr. Malony was awarded the NSF National Young Investigator award in 1994. In 1999 he was a Fulbright Research Scholar to Austria resident at the University of Vienna. Dr. Malony was awarded the prestigious Alexander von Humboldt Research Award for Senior U.S. Scientists by the Alexander von Humboldt Foundation in 2002. He was promoted to Full Professor in 2004.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Department of Computer and Information Science; Unversity of Oregon; M.S.; University of California; University of Illinois; Urbana-Champaign; Hewlett-Packard Laboratories; University of Illinois Center for Supercomputing Research and Development; Fulbright Research Scholar; Utrecht University; NSF National Young Investigator; Fulbright Research Scholar; University of Vienna; Alexander von Humboldt Research Award; Alexander von Humboldt Foundation; 	PERSON: Dr. Allen D. Malony; Malony; Malony; Malony; Dr. Malony; Dr. Malony; 	DATE: 1980; 1982; 1990; 1981; 1985; 1986; 1991; 1991; 1994; 1999; 2002; 2004; 	LOCATION: Los Angeles; Palo Alto; California; Oregon; The Netherlands; Austria; U.S.; 	NOUN: Dr. Allen D. Malony; Professor; Department; Computer; Information Science; Unversity; Oregon; Malony; B.S.; M.S.; Computer Science; University; California; Los Angeles; Ph.D. degree; University; Illinois; Urbana-Champaign; October; Malony; Hewlett-Packard Laboratories; Palo Alto; California; Software Engineer; University; Illinois Center; Supercomputing Research; Development; leader; performance evaluation project; Cedar multiprocessor; Malony; faculty; Oregon; year; Fulbright Research Scholar; Professor; Utrecht University; Netherlands; Dr. Malony; NSF National Young Investigator award; Fulbright Research Scholar; Austria resident; University; Vienna; Dr. Malony; Alexander von Humboldt Research Award; U.S. Scientists; Alexander von Humboldt Foundation; Professor; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

4f8e5b50e80eb0e498ec1488 0 28----Research----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	energi:1 understand:1 tool:1 particular:1 challeng:1 perform:10 scalabl:1 foundat:1 supercomput:1 center:1 open:1 diagnosi:1 interest:1 characterizi:1 fund:1 work:2 creat:1 scientif:1 art:1 environ:1 wide:1 code:1 tune:1 hpc:2 nation:2 project:1 appli:1 system:1 tau:1 comput:2 sourc:1 result:1 depart:1 behavior:1 data:1 state:1 automat:1 applic:1 pose:1 maloni:1 current:1 mine:1 analysi:4 develop:1 scienc:1 dr:1 softwar:1 direct:1 parallel:2 includ:1 problem:1 us:1 toolsuit:1 kernel:1 research:4 laboratori:2 measur:1 prl:2	||	Dr. Malony's research interests are in parallel computing, performance analysis, supercomputing, and scientific software environments. Scalable high-performance computing (HPC) poses challenging problems for characteriziing and understanding performance behavior and applying analysis results to application code tuning. The Performance Research Laboratory (PRL), directed by Malony, works on projects, funded by the Department of Energy and the National Science Foundation, to develop parallel performance measurement and analysis tools. In particular, the TAU performance system is a state-of-the-art, open source performance toolsuite created by PRL and used widely in national laboratories and HPC research centers. Current research includes work in automatic performance diagnosis, kernel and I/O performance analysis, and performance data mining.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Performance Research Laboratory; Department of Energy; National Science Foundation; TAU; PRL; HPC; 	PERSON: Dr. Malony; Malony; 	NOUN: Dr. Malony; research interests; computing; performance analysis; supercomputing; software environments; computing; HPC; problems; performance behavior; analysis; application code tuning; Performance Research Laboratory; PRL; Malony; projects; Department; Energy; National Science Foundation; performance measurement; analysis tools; TAU performance system; source performance toolsuite; PRL; laboratories; HPC research centers; research; work; performance diagnosis; kernel; I\/O performance analysis; performance data mining; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
4f8e5b50e80eb0e498ec1488 0 29----Research----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	oregon:1 integr:1 gener:1 servic:1 tool:1 mri:1 next:1 perform:1 prototyp:1 network:1 center:1 univers:1 interest:1 neurosci:1 combin:1 grid:1 analysi:1 develop:1 brain:1 dr:1 neuroinformat:1 extend:1 nic:3 us:1 neuroimag:1 director:1 deliveri:1 technolog:1 research:2 eeg:1 process:1 inform:1 system:2 advanc:1 base:1 comput:2 method:1 medic:1	||	Dr. Malony's research interests extend to computing and information processing systems for neuroscience research. He is the Director of the NeuroInformatics Center (NIC) at the University of Oregon. The NIC is developing advanced integrated neuroimaging tools that combine EEG and MRI methods for next-generation brain analysis. Grid technologies and high-performance computing are being used by the NIC to prototype network-based systems for medical service delivery.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: University of Oregon; NIC; 	PERSON: Dr. Malony; 	NOUN: Dr. Malony; research interests; computing; information processing systems; neuroscience research; Director; NeuroInformatics Center; NIC; University; Oregon; NIC; neuroimaging tools; EEG; MRI methods; brain analysis; Grid technologies; computing; NIC; prototype; systems; service delivery; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

Shustek Chair Professor in Computer Science Polytechnic Institute of NYU. He is also the Head of the Departement of Computer Science and Engineering. Before joining NYU-Poly, he was a professor at University of Pennsylvania (13 years) and Eurecom Institute (5 years) in France. at Pin January 2003. He received a B.S.E.E from Tufts University, a M.S.E.E. from Columbia University, and a Ph.D. in Computer and Control Engineering from The University of Michigan.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Computer Science Polytechnic Institute of NYU; Head of the Departement of Computer Science and Engineering; University of Pennsylvania; Eurecom Institute; Tufts University; Columbia University; Control Engineering; The University of Michigan; 	PERSON: Keith Ross; Leonard J. He is an ACM Fellow, IEEE Fellow, recipient of the Infocom 2009 Best Paper Award (1,435 papers submitted), and recipient of 2008 and the 2011 Best Paper Awards for Multimedia Communications (awarded by IEEE Communications Society). 4f8e5b80e80eb0e463081588 1 22----Bio----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.LI.UL.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	model:1 springer:1 kuros:1 loss:1 overal:1 languag:1 monograph:1 exclud:1 network:3 author:2 weslei:1 sixth:1 internation:1 publish:2 fourteen:1 introductori:1 addison:1 top:1 ross:2 fifth:1 textbook:4 jame:1 multiservic:1 edit:2 translat:1 research:1 nation:1 cs:1 co:1 program:1 popular:3 featur:1 professor:2 commun:1 broadband:1 approach:1 comput:2 internet:1	||	Professor Ross is co-author (with James F. Kurose) of the popular textbook, Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach Featuring the Internet, published by Addison-Wesley (first edition in 2000, sixth edition 2012). It is the most popular textbook on computer networking, both nationally and internationally, and has been translated into fourteen languages. Excluding introductory programming textbooks, it is the fifth most popular CS textbook overall. Professor Ross is also the author of the research monograph, Multiservice Loss Models for Broadband Communication Networks, published by Springer in 1995.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Addison-Wesley; Multiservice Loss Models for Broadband Communication Networks; 	PERSON: Ross; James F. 4f8e5b6ae80eb0e41f011588 3 1----Bio----#text.B.P.BODY.HTML.#document	short:1 bio:1	||	Short bio:	##true@@false$$		||	NOUN: bio; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
4f8e5b6ae80eb0e41f011588 3 2----Bio----#text.B.P.BODY.HTML.#document	phd:1 gener:1 februari:1 diffus:1 interest:1 video:2 elect:1 lausann:1 respons:1 hold:1 feder:1 neuv:1 catholiqu:1 partial:1 board:1 degre:1 namur:1 editor:2 editori:1 ieee:2 european:1 professor:1 ucl:1 committe:1 review:1 born:1 mri:1 lt:1 multimod:2 de:1 associ:1 current:2 mlsp:1 analysi:4 eng:1 publish:4 institut:1 scienc:1 dr:1 member:3 technic:1 louvain:2 receiv:1 join:1 registr:1 technolog:1 process:7 intern:3 method:1 respect:1 jean:1 eusipco:1 integr:1 segment:2 patent:1 prior:1 confer:2 variat:1 proceed:1 elsevi:1 chief:1 surgeri:1 januari:1 thiran:2 scientif:1 assist:2 belgium:2 imag:8 co:2 la:1 comput:1 lectur:1 senior:2 medic:1 chairman:1 springer:1 paper:2 knowledg:1 universit:1 hindawi:1 signal:6 swiss:1 journal:2 author:2 chapter:1 philipp:1 societi:1 switzerland:1 peer:1 equat:1 includ:2 ivmsp:1 laboratori:1 book:1 group:1 epfl:1 differenti:1	||	Jean-Philippe Thiran was born in Namur, Belgium, in 1970. He received the Elect. Eng. and Ph.D. degrees from the Universite catholique de Louvain (UCL), Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium, in 1993 and 1997, respectively. He joined the Signal Processing Laboratory (LTS) of the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology (EPFL), Lausanne, Switzerland, in February 1998 as a Senior Lecturer. Since January 2004, he has been an Assistant Professor, responsible for the Image Analysis Group. His current scientific interests include image segmentation, prior knowledge integration in image analysis, partial differential equations and variational methods in image analysis, multimodal signal processing, medical image analysis, including multimodal image registration, segmentation, computer-assisted surgery, and diffusion MRI. He is author or co-author of two 4 book chapters, 69 journal papers, and some 130 peer-reviewed papers published in proceedings of international conferences. He holds four international patents. Dr. Thiran was Co-Editor-in-Chief of Signal Processing (published by Elsevier Science) from 2001 to 2005. He is currently an Associate Editor of the International Journal of Image and Video Processing (published by Hindawi), and member of the Editorial Board of Signal, Image and Video Processing (published by Springer). He was the General Chairman of the 2008 European Signal Processing Conference (EUSIPCO 2008). From 2004 to 2011 he was an Assistant Professor (tenure track), responsible for the image analysis group (LTS5). In a few years he has built a research team of some 20 researchers, both PhD students and post-docs, active in various areas of signal, image and multimodal data analysis. In March 2011 Dr Thiran has been promoted to Associate Professor in Signal Processing at EPFL. He also holds a 20% associate professor position with the Department of Radiology of the University Hospital Center and University of Lausanne (CHUV-UNIL).	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Signal Processing Institute; Swiss Federal Institute of Technology; Department of Radiology of the University Hospital Center and University of Lausanne; 	PERSON: Jean-Philippe Thiran; Dr Thiran; 	DATE: 1998; 2004; 2011; 2011; 	LOCATION: Lausanne; Switzerland; 	NOUN: Dr Jean-Philippe Thiran; Signal Processing Institute; ITS; Swiss Federal Institute; Technology; EPFL; Lausanne; Switzerland; February; lecturer; Assistant Professor; tenure track; image analysis group; LTS5; years; research team; researchers; PhD students; post-docs; areas; signal; image; data analysis; March; Dr Thiran; Associate Professor; Signal Processing; EPFL; %; professor position; Department; Radiology; University Hospital Center; University; Lausanne; CHUV-UNIL; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

He holds 5 international patents. From 2001 to 2005 he was Co-Editor-in-Chief of the Signal Processing international journal (published by Elsevier Science). He is currently an associate editor of the IEEE Trnsactions on Image Processing, of the International Journal of Image and Video Processing, published by Hindawi Publishing Corp., and member of the editorial board of the journal Signal, Image and Video Processing , published by Springer. He is also an Adjunct Professor with the Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, University of California, Berkeley. 4f8e5b80e80eb0e477081588 3 4----Research----#text.SPAN.SPAN.SPAN.SPAN.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.LI.UL.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	accept:1 visit:1 doctor:2 confer:1 student:1 scheme:1 univers:2 year:1 effici:1 yang:1 select:1 calcul:1 environ:1 candid:1 databas:1 nation:1 queri:1 project:1 inform:1 obtain:1 zhou:1 professor:3 distinguish:1 make:1 solut:1 queensland:2 paper:2 set:1 partit:1 data:1 talent:1 papar:1 xiaofang:1 top:1 parallel:1 regular:1 hyperplan:1 origin:1 particip:1 problem:2 us:1 thousand:1 jing:1 research:1 school:1 effect:1 larg:1 advisor:1 intern:1 group:1 studi:3 skylin:1	||	A paper by group of Professor Xiaofang Zhou, who is a National one-thousand-talents scheme selected candidate, distinguished Professor and Doctoral advisor, Professor at the University of Queensland, was accepted as regular paper by the top international conference SIGMOD2011 on database. The papar studied the problem of effective calculation on SKYLINE queries, and they used the way of hyperplane projection to partition large data sets, making the original problem obtain a more efficient solution in parallel environment. Yang Jing, a doctor in the School of Information, who had studied and made research as a visiting student at the University of Queensland for a year, also participated in this study.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: University of Queensland; School of Information; University of Queensland; 	PERSON: Xiaofang Zhou; Yang Jing; 	NOUN: paper; group; Professor Xiaofang Zhou; National one-thousand-talents scheme; candidate; Professor; Doctoral advisor; Professor; University; Queensland; paper; conference SIGMOD2011; database; papar; problem; calculation; SKYLINE queries; way; hyperplane projection; partition; data sets; problem; solution; environment; Yang Jing; doctor; School; Information; research; student; University; Queensland; year; study; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##true@@false$$

4f8e5b81e80eb0e444091588 4 3----Bio----#text.A.PRE.BODY.HTML.#document	phd:1 understand:1 visit:1 crypto:2 faculti:2 center:2 time:2 aviv:2 oper:1 role:1 import:1 host:1 art:1 director:2 cite:1 system:2 wwwcsbuedu:1 http:1 advanc:1 professor:3 expert:1 depart:2 data:1 spring:1 applic:1 algorithm:2 modern:1 authent:2 pleas:1 boston:2 associ:2 side:1 current:1 mine:1 built:1 institut:2 theoret:1 scienc:4 sincer:1 handheld:1 messag:1 come:1 checkpoint:1 us:3 semin:1 receiv:1 mit:1 join:2 research:4 intro:1 chair:1 welcom:2 compon:1 stan:2 fall:1 cloud:1 mainfram:1 tel:2 lead:1 dear:1 scientist:1 tj:1 bu:1 kei:1 student:1 univers:4 cryptograph:1 colleg:1 work:1 weizmann:1 sclaroff:1 composit:1 billion:1 preserv:1 dai:1 togeth:1 bellar:1 canetti:1 inform:2 co:1 hmac:1 reliabl:1 program:1 comput:4 pleasur:1 internet:1 result:1 krawczyk:1 can:1 watson:1 cyber:1 staff:1 privaci:1 risc:1 graduat:1 serv:2 develop:2 agenda:1 protocol:2 includ:2 standard:1 task:1 agreement:1 produc:1 problem:1 thousand:1 teach:1 school:1 secur:6 obfusc:1 ran:7 plai:1 improv:1	||	Dear Faculty, Staff, and Students, It is my sincere pleasure to welcome Professor Ran Canetti to our department. Ran comes to us from Tel Aviv University, where he served as an Associate Professor of Computer Science and the Director of the Checkpoint Institute for Information Security. Ran is a leading expert in cryptographic protocols and computer security. He has played an important role in the development of algorithms and Internet standards for such tasks as key agreement and message authentication. His HMAC authentication algorithm (co-developed with Bellare and Krawczyk) is built into every modern operating system from mainframes to handhelds, and is used billions of times a day. On the theoretical side, his seminal work on protocol composition (which has been cited thousands of times) has improved our understanding of how secure components can be put together to produce a secure result. His current research agenda includes the problem of program obfuscation, which could be used for a host of applications including secure cloud computing and privacy-preserving data mining. Ran received his Ph.D. from the Weizmann Institute of Science. Before joining the faculty of Tel-Aviv University, he was a researcher at IBM's T.J. Watson Research Center and a visiting scientist at MIT. Ran will be teaching CS538 (Intro Crypto) this fall, and CS548 (Advanced Crypto) this spring. Ran will also serve as the Associate Director for Research in the BU Center for Reliable Information Systems & Cyber Security (RISCS). Please join me in welcoming Ran to Boston University! Stan -- Stan Sclaroff Professor and Chair Department of Computer Science College and Graduate School of Arts and Sciences Boston University	##false@@false$$	http://www.cs.bu.edu/	##false@@true$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Computer Science; Checkpoint Institute for Information Security; Weizmann Institute of Science; Tel-Aviv University; IBM; T.J. He received his Ph. D from National Laboratory of Pattern Recognition, Chinese Academy of Sciences, in 2003, and his MS from SouthEast University in 2000. Before he joined in Rutgers University, he worked as an associate professor at the National Laboratory of Pattern Recognition, Chinese Academic of Science, and he worked as an associate researcher at the Multimedia Laboratory in Chinese University of Hong Kong during June, 2004 and April, 2005. He received the president scholarship of Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2003. His research interests are Image and Vision Analysis including Face Image Analysis, Graph & Hyper-graph based Image and Video understanding, Medical Image Analysis, Event-based Video Analysis, etc. He has published more than 80 papers in journals and conferences. He is an editorial board member of NeuroComputing and the Journal of Advance in Multimedia, and he is a guest editor of IEEE Transaction on Multimedia, Computer Vision & Image Understanding, and Pattern Recognition Letters. He is a senior member of the IEEE.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Rutgers University; National Laboratory of Pattern Recognition , Chinese Academy of Sciences; SouthEast University; Rutgers University; National Laboratory of Pattern Recognition; Chinese Academic of Science; Chinese Academy of Sciences; Graph & Hyper-graph; Image and Video; Journal of Advance; Computer Vision & Image Understanding; Pattern Recognition Letters; 	PERSON: Dr Qingshan Liu; 	DATE: 2003; 2000; 2004; 2005; 2003; 	LOCATION: Hong Kong; 	NOUN: Dr Qingshan Liu; research professor; department; computer science; biomedicine; modeling center; Rutgers University; Ph.; D; National Laboratory; Pattern Recognition; Academy; Sciences; MS; SouthEast University; Rutgers University; professor; National Laboratory; Pattern Recognition; Academic; Science; researcher; Multimedia Laboratory; Chinese University; Hong Kong; June; April; president scholarship; Academy; Sciences; research interests; Image; Vision Analysis; Face Image Analysis; Graph; Hyper-graph; Image; Video understanding; Medical Image Analysis; Video Analysis; papers; journals; conferences; editorial board member; NeuroComputing; Journal; Advance; Multimedia; guest editor; IEEE Transaction; Multimedia; Computer Vision; Image; Pattern Recognition Letters; member; IEEE; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

During that time, Karp did foundational work on models of parallel computation, which involves the simultaneous use of multiple coordinated computers to solve a single problem. 4f8e5b51e80eb0e42aed1488 2 5----Research----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	particularli:1 np:6 unclassifi:1 show:1 travel:1 function:1 time:1 independ:1 correct:1 equival:1 elus:2 among:1 expand:1 import:1 focus:1 effici:8 sens:1 cook:1 prove:2 whose:1 signific:1 career:1 shown:1 class:1 convinc:1 suggest:1 lack:1 provid:1 solv:2 salesmen:1 size:1 peopl:1 input:2 grown:1 known:1 case:1 combinatori:4 todai:1 collect:1 solut:1 concept:1 paper:3 talent:1 leonid:1 run:1 difficult:2 strongli:1 algorithm:6 introduc:1 tsp:3 importantli:1 notori:1 solvabl:1 stephen:1 initi:1 exist:1 hard:1 classic:2 find:1 heurist:1 complet:6 karp:1 addit:1 twenti:1 levin:1 includ:2 failur:1 worst:1 establish:1 problem:12 semin:1 thousand:1 framework:1 research:1 sever:1 classifi:1 specif:1 remain:1 ad:1 reduc:1 polynomi:1 bound:1 explan:2 berkelei:1	||	Karp's initial research at Berkeley focused on	##false@@false$$	heuristic algorithms	##false@@true$$	for hard combinatorial problems, particularly for the notoriously difficult	##false@@false$$	Traveling Salesmen Problem	##true@@true$$	(TSP). Like many combinatorial problems, there was no efficient TSP algorithm that could be proved correct for all input, and whose worst-case running time is bounded by a polynomial function of the input size. Also lacking was an explanation of why an efficient algorithm had been so elusive. In one of the most significant paper of his career, Karp's 1972	##false@@false$$	Reducibility Among Combinatorial Problems	##true@@true$$	provided a convincing explanation for the elusiveness of an efficient solution. In that seminal paper, Karp expanded on the concept (first introduced by Stephen Cook in 1971, and independently by Leonid Levin) of NP-completeness and proved that if any of twenty-one well-known difficult problems (including TSP) could be solved by an efficient algorithm, then all of the problems could be efficiently solved.	##false@@false$$	NP-completeness	##false@@true$$	shows, in an important sense, that these 21 problems are all equivalent. The collective failure by many talented people to find efficient algorithms for specific NP-complete problems strongly suggests that no efficient algorithm exists for any of them. Importantly, the paper established a framework for adding additional problems to the class of NP-complete problems, which has since grown to include many thousands. Today, only one or two classic combinatorial problems remain unclassified as to whether they are NP-complete or not. While most of the classified classic problems are NP-complete, several have been shown to be efficiently solvable.	##false@@false$$		||	PERSON: Karp; Karp; Karp; Stephen Cook; Leonid Levin; 	DATE: 1972; 1971; 	LOCATION: Berkeley; 	NOUN: Karp; research; Berkeley; heuristic algorithms; problems; Salesmen Problem; TSP; problems; TSP algorithm; input; time; function; input size; explanation; algorithm; paper; career; Karp; Reducibility; Combinatorial Problems; explanation; elusiveness; solution; paper; Karp; concept; Stephen Cook; Leonid Levin; NP-completeness; problems; TSP; algorithm; problems; NP-completeness shows; sense; problems; failure; people; algorithms; problems; algorithm; paper; framework; problems; class; problems; thousands; Today; problems; problems; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
4f8e5b51e80eb0e42aed1488 2 6----Research----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	solut:2 essenc:1 np:3 substanti:1 scientist:1 difficult:1 consid:1 open:2 correct:1 verifi:1 import:2 question:3 theoret:1 examin:1 famou:1 scienc:1 find:1 complet:1 work:1 unsolv:1 mathemat:1 problem:2 inher:1 discuss:1 comput:2 ask:1 mathematician:1 propos:1 motiv:1	||	Karp's work on NP-completeness substantially motivated the discussion of the famous unsolved	##false@@false$$	P = NP	##true@@true$$	question	##false@@true$$	and its further examination by mathematicians and computer scientists. In essence, P = NP asks whether finding a solution to a problem is inherently more difficult than verifying that a proposed solution is correct. Not only is the problem considered the most important open question in theoretical computer science, it is also one of the most important open questions in mathematics.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: NP; NP; 	PERSON: Karp; 	NOUN: Karp; work; NP-completeness; discussion; P; NP question; examination; mathematicians; computer scientists; essence; P; NP; solution; problem; solution; problem; question; computer science; questions; mathematics; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
4f8e5b51e80eb0e42aed1488 2 7----Research----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	particularli:1 gener:1 np:1 etc:1 cycl:1 award:1 show:1 flow:4 amount:1 year:1 effici:2 recipi:1 limit:1 edmond:1 hopcroft:2 wire:1 signific:1 ture:1 number:1 wide:1 solv:1 steadi:1 non:1 huge:1 bit:1 co:1 liquid:1 maximum:1 materi:1 comput:2 commun:1 sourc:1 case:1 match:3 bipartit:3 jack:1 can:3 edg:1 paper:2 john:1 state:1 road:1 applic:1 network:8 pipe:2 algorithm:2 author:1 graph:1 transport:1 scienc:1 aris:1 complet:1 karp:2 optim:1 physic:2 us:1 problem:6 biolog:1 differ:1 exampl:2 special:1 capac:1 studi:1 bound:1 destin:1	||	The year after his paper on NP-completeness, Karp co-authored with Jack Edmonds and	##false@@false$$	John Hopcroft	##false@@true$$	(himself a Turing Award recipient) two very significant papers on efficient algorithms for network flow and	##false@@false$$	bipartite graph matching	##false@@true$$	. The network flow problem is to compute the maximum steady-state amount of material (for example, liquids in a pipe or bits in a communication network) that can be transported from a source to a destination in a network, where each edge (pipe, wire, road etc.) in the network can have a different but bounded capacity. This is one of the most widely studied problems in optimization and algorithmic computer science, and is not limited to physical networks as the same problems arise in, for example, biological cycles. The bipartite matching problem is a particularly useful special case of network flow that has a huge number of non-physical applications. Karp and Hopcroft showed in 1973 that the bipartite matching problem can be solved more efficiently than the general network flow problem [	##false@@false$$	] .	##false@@false$$		||	PERSON: Karp; Jack Edmonds; John Hopcroft; Karp; Hopcroft; 	DATE: 1973; 	NOUN: year; paper; NP-completeness; Karp; Jack Edmonds; John Hopcroft; Turing Award; papers; algorithms; network flow; graph matching; network flow problem; maximum; amount; material; example; liquids; pipe; bits; communication network; source; destination; network; edge; pipe; wire; road etc.; network; capacity; problems; optimization; computer science; networks; problems; example; cycles; matching problem; case; network flow; number; applications; Karp; Hopcroft; matching problem; network flow problem; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
4f8e5b51e80eb0e42aed1488 2 8----Research----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	characterist:1 model:1 can:1 behavior:1 distribut:1 possibl:1 particular:1 becam:1 activ:1 space:1 run:3 specifi:1 algorithm:8 expect:2 time:3 probabl:1 univers:1 fix:1 determinist:1 interest:1 began:1 rather:2 effici:1 analysi:4 question:1 examin:1 find:1 drawn:1 major:1 karp:1 surprisingli:1 assum:1 later:1 worst:1 theme:1 random:3 us:1 averag:1 accord:1 research:1 input:5 compon:1 often:1 reduc:1 significantli:1 case:1 probabilist:3 design:2	||	Another major theme in Karp's research has been the use of probability in both the design and analysis of efficient algorithms. Karp's interest in the probabilistic analysis of algorithms began in the 1980s, when he examined questions of the average, rather than the worst-case, running times of particular algorithms. In probabilistic analysis, the algorithm is fixed and	##false@@false$$	deterministic	##false@@true$$	, but its input is assumed to be drawn from a space universe of possible inputs according to a well-specified probabilistic model. The analysis finds the expected running time (or other characteristic) for that distribution of inputs. Karp later became active in the design of	##false@@false$$	randomized algorithms	##false@@true$$	, where the algorithm itself, rather than the input to the algorithm, has a random component. Surprisingly, randomizing the behavior of an algorithm can often significantly reduce its expected running time for any input.	##false@@false$$		||	PERSON: Karp; Karp; Karp; 	NOUN: theme; Karp; research; use; probability; design; analysis; algorithms; Karp; interest; analysis; algorithms; questions; average; times; algorithms; analysis; algorithm; input; space universe; inputs; model; analysis; time; distribution; inputs; Karp; design; algorithms; algorithm; input; algorithm; component; behavior; algorithm; time; input; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
4f8e5b51e80eb0e42aed1488 2 9----Research----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	becam:1 issu:1 recent:1 biologi:2 algorithm:3 indirect:1 help:1 given:1 dna:1 full:1 rang:1 sequenc:1 experiment:1 began:2 map:1 import:1 especi:1 examin:2 karp:2 work:1 limit:1 gene:3 locat:2 genom:2 physic:2 avail:1 devis:1 wide:1 research:1 begin:1 human:1 field:1 inform:1 project:1 grow:1 determin:1 influenc:1 comput:1 afford:1 rapidli:1	||	Karp's most recent research has been in computational biology. This work began in the 1990s, as the field began to grow rapidly under the influence of the Human Genome Project. Karp first examined physical mapping of genes, devising algorithms to help determine the physical location of genes in a genome given the limited indirect experimental information about gene location. Such algorithms were especially important before affordable full DNA sequencing became available. From that beginning, Karp has examined a wide range of algorithmic issues in biology, such as:	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Human Genome Project; 	PERSON: Karp; Karp; Karp; 	NOUN: Karp; research; biology; work; field; influence; Genome Project; Karp; mapping; genes; algorithms; location; genes; genome; information; gene location; algorithms; DNA sequencing; beginning; Karp; range; issues; biology; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

4f8e5b51e80eb0e42aed1488 2 16----Education----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	creation:1 depart:1 thirti:1 appoint:1 engin:1 award:2 scientist:1 eight:1 washington:1 time:1 univers:3 prestigi:1 bioengin:1 current:1 left:1 academi:2 institut:2 major:1 scienc:5 karp:3 addit:1 elect:2 includ:1 kyoto:1 titl:1 california:1 mathemat:1 return:1 us:1 molecular:1 research:1 nation:3 prize:1 professor:2 intern:1 comput:3 biotechnolog:1 medal:1 adjunct:1 senior:1 berkelei:3 princip:1	||	In 1995 Karp left Berkeley for the Department of Computer Science at the University of Washington, where he was also an Adjunct Professor of Molecular Biotechnology. He returned to Berkeley in 1999 with appointments in Computer Science, Mathematics, and Bioengineering. In addition, Karp is a Senior Research Scientist at the International Computer Science Institute in Berkeley, and was a principal in the creation of the Institute. Karp is currently a University Professor at the University of California, a prestigious title that has been awarded only thirty-eight times. Other major awards include election to the National Academy of Sciences in 1980, election to the National Academy of Engineering in 1992, the U.S. National Medal of Science in 1996, and the Kyoto Prize in 2008.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Department of Computer Science; University of Washington; Computer Science; Senior Research Scientist; International Computer Science Institute; Institute; University; University of California; National Academy of Sciences; National Academy of Engineering; U.S. National Medal of Science; 	PERSON: Karp; Karp; Karp; 	DATE: 1995; 1999; 1980; 1992; 1996; 2008; 	LOCATION: Berkeley; Berkeley; Berkeley; 	NOUN: Karp; Berkeley; Department; Computer Science; University; Washington; Adjunct Professor; Biotechnology; Berkeley; appointments; Computer Science; Mathematics; Bioengineering; addition; Karp; Senior Research Scientist; International Computer Science Institute; Berkeley; principal; creation; Institute; Karp; University Professor; University; California; title; times; awards; election; National Academy; Sciences; election; National Academy; Engineering; U.S. National Medal; Science; Kyoto Prize; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

4f8e5b51e80eb0e42aed1488 0 2----Bio----#text.P.DIV.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.BODY.HTML.#document	phd:2 fulkerson:1 attend:1 thirti:1 award:3 french:1 philosoph:1 scientist:1 faculti:1 eight:1 center:1 supervis:1 lectureship:1 oper:1 univers:1 honorari:1 academi:3 miller:1 dissert:1 honor:1 genom:1 art:1 ibm:1 technion:1 ture:1 class:1 nation:2 degre:1 present:2 lanchest:1 machineri:1 advanc:1 prize:5 professor:2 harvard:2 distinguish:1 comput:3 fellow:1 lectur:1 medal:2 harvei:1 centenni:1 depart:1 engin:1 activ:1 network:1 algorithm:1 six:1 von:2 boston:1 associ:2 societi:1 american:3 current:1 institut:2 neumann:2 scienc:8 member:2 held:1 includ:1 manag:1 mathemat:1 babbag:1 receiv:1 us:2 teach:1 research:5 chair:1 school:1 latin:1 intern:1 theori:1 method:1 uc:1 berkelei:5	||	He attended Boston Latin School and Harvard University, receiving the Ph.D. in 1959. From 1959 to 1968 he was a member of the Mathematical Sciences Department at IBM Research. From 1968 to 1994 and from 1999 to the present he has been a professor at UC Berkeley, where he held the Class of 1939 Chair. From 1988 to 1995 and 1999 to the present he has been a Research Scientist at the International Computer Science Institute in Berkeley. His current activities center on algorithmic methods in genomics and computer networking. He has supervised thirty-six Ph.D. dissertations. Honors and awards include: U.S. National Medal of Science, Turing Award, Fulkerson Prize, Harvey Prize (Technion), Centennial Medal (Harvard), Lanchester Prize, Von Neumann Theory Prize, Von Neumann Lectureship, Distinguished Teaching Award (Berkeley), Faculty Research Lecturer (Berkeley), Miller Research Professor (Berkeley), Babbage Prize and eight honorary degrees. He is a member of the U.S. National Academies of Sciences and Engineering, the American Philosophical Society and the French Academy of Sciences, and a Fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, the American Association for the Advancement of Science, the Association for Computing Machinery and the Institute for Operations Research and Management Science.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Boston Latin School; 4f8e5b50e80eb0e419ed1488 5 13----Research----#text.P.DIV.ARTICLE.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	instructor:1 flow:1 close:1 cover:1 student:3 instruct:1 ok:2 work:3 topic:1 minut:1 hash:1 class:3 learn:1 theater:1 togeth:2 solv:1 prepar:1 whiteboard:1 appli:1 co:1 program:1 materi:1 often:1 proce:1 lot:1 lectur:2 try:1 util:1 todai:1 thing:1 go:1 deliber:1 concept:1 awai:1 ll:1 re:1 algorithm:1 pfen:1 style:1 dialogu:1 implement:1 develop:1 slide:1 want:1 peer:1 let:1 coin:2 come:1 problem:1 front:1 us:1 accompani:1 teach:1 sever:1 techniqu:1 tabl:1 instead:1 exampl:1 wai:1 preconfigur:1 improvis:1	||	Ok, now what about his teaching style? One thing Pfenning does	##false@@false$$	not	##true@@false$$	do is get in front of his class and lecture away for the 90 minutes. Instead, he uses several techniques, one of which his co-instructor has coined Improvisational Theater and the other he coined Deliberate Programming. In the first, he works very closely with his students to develop the material and flow of class, utilizing a lot of dialogue and peer instruction. He often comes to class prepared with a topic he wants to cover (but with no accompanying slides or preconfigured lectures) and says (for example), Ok, we re going to learn hash tables today. Then he proceeds to work with his students from his whiteboard to problem-solve together. Once the algorithm or concept is implemented, he ll let students work together and try to apply it in their own ways.	##false@@false$$		||	PERSON: Pfenning; 	NOUN: Ok; teaching style; thing Pfenning; front; class; minutes; techniques; co-instructor; Theater; Deliberate Programming; students; material; flow; class; lot; dialogue; instruction; class; topic; slides; example; Ok; tables today; students; whiteboard; algorithm; concept; students; ways; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

4f8e5b50e80eb0e419ed1488 5 15----Others----#text.P.DIV.ARTICLE.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	deliber:1 call:1 idea:1 hundr:1 don:1 can:1 catch:1 lead:1 run:1 earli:1 ensur:1 emploi:1 mai:1 pfen:1 time:1 student:2 encourag:1 write:1 screen:1 confid:1 previous:1 watch:1 ey:2 select:1 random:1 class:1 describ:1 problem:1 code:4 team:1 techniqu:1 familiar:1 appli:1 homework:1 program:2 mistak:1 lectur:3 big:1 compil:1	||	The second technique Pfenning employs during lecture is his again what he calls, Deliberate Programming, which I was not previously familiar. As he describes, it s an idea that we should write code in such a way that we should be confident that it can compile and run the first time. This is then applied in lecture team-coding and encourages students to program this way in their homework. He may also select a few students at random during lecture to lead problem before the class with hundreds of eyes watching the code up on the big screen. He says, You put that many eyes on the code and it ensures they don t make mistakes or if they do, they catch them early on.	##false@@false$$		||	PERSON: Pfenning; 	NOUN: technique Pfenning; lecture; Deliberate Programming; idea; code; way; time; lecture team-coding; students; way; homework; students; lecture; problem; class; hundreds; eyes; code; screen; eyes; code; t; mistakes; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

4f8e5b80e80eb0e487081588 2 2----Bio----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	jean:2 bchi:1 markup:1 lead:1 languag:2 sigchi:1 belgian:1 taskforc:1 toward:1 action:1 chief:1 founder:1 iag:1 work:1 coordin:2 creat:1 lsm:1 descript:1 belgium:1 catholiqu:1 cost:1 editor:1 co:1 ieee:1 machin:1 european:2 definit:1 vanderdonckt:2 professor:1 comput:2 commun:1 senior:1 usixml:2 springer:1 seri:1 structur:1 common:1 engin:1 universit:1 maus:1 activ:2 network:1 de:1 consortium:1 full:1 extens:1 sesami:1 usabl:1 scienc:1 hci:2 similar:2 member:2 acm:1 louvain:2 manag:1 excel:1 research:1 human:4 school:1 interfac:3 book:1 laboratori:1 interact:1 usag:1 within:1 group:1 user:2	||	Jean Vanderdonckt	##true@@false$$	is Full Professor in Computer Science at Universit catholique de Louvain (Belgium), Louvain School of Management (IAG-LSM) where he leads the Belgian Laboratory of Computer-Human Interaction (BCHI). Jean Vanderdonckt is the founder and the coordinator of the UsiXML Consortium that structures activities towards the definition and the usage of UsiXML (User Interface eXtensible Markup Language) as a common User Interface Description Language. He is the coordinator of HCI activities within the Similar network of excellence (The European research taskforce creating human-machine interfaces SIMILAR to human-human communication). He is also a member of the European COST n 294 Action MAUSE on usability engineering and of the SESAMI Working Group. He is a Senior member of IEEE, ACM, and SIGCHI. He is also co-editor in chief of Springer HCI Series of books.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Computer Science; Louvain; Louvain School of Management; HCI; SIGCHI; 	PERSON: Jean Vanderdonckt; Jean Vanderdonckt; Springer; 	LOCATION: Belgium; 	NOUN: Jean Vanderdonckt; Professor; Computer Science; Universit; Louvain; Belgium; Louvain School; Management; IAG-LSM; Laboratory; Computer-Human Interaction; BCHI; Jean Vanderdonckt; founder; coordinator; UsiXML Consortium; structures activities; definition; usage; UsiXML; User Interface eXtensible Markup Language; User Interface Description Language; coordinator; HCI activities; network; excellence; research taskforce; interfaces SIMILAR; communication; member; COST n; Action MAUSE; usability engineering; SESAMI Working Group; member; IEEE; ACM; SIGCHI; co-editor; chief; Springer HCI Series; books; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
4f8e5b80e80eb0e487081588 2 3----Others----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	phd:1 award:1 belgian:1 manuel:2 univers:1 interest:1 thesi:1 iag:1 mexico:1 lsm:1 astrophys:1 assist:1 belgium:1 workflow:1 nation:1 degre:1 system:1 pursu:1 comput:4 cathol:1 ucl:3 usixml:1 model:3 callero:2 engin:2 lab:1 dea:1 consortium:1 cockpit:1 driven:2 electron:1 develop:1 juan:2 institut:1 scienc:3 complet:1 member:1 gonzalez:2 includ:1 scholarship:1 louvain:2 manag:1 receiv:2 came:1 research:2 master:1 human:1 school:1 interfac:4 interact:1 user:4 design:1 optic:1	||	Juan Manuel Gonzalez Calleros	##true@@false$$	is a Researcher assistant of the University catholic of Louvain (UCL). He is member of the Belgian Lab of Human Computer Interaction and of the UsiXML consortium. Having received a scholarship award, he came to Belgium and completed his DEA in computer Science from UCL. He received a master degree in Computer Sciences at National Institute of Astrophysics, Optics and Electronic (Mexico). Juan Manuel Gonzalez Calleros is pursuing a PhD in Computer Sciences with the thesis model Driven engineering of 3D User Interfaces at UCL, Louvain School of Management (IAG-LSM). His research interests include workflow models, Model-Driven engineering for developing User Interfaces, 3D User Interfaces, and User Interface for cockpit systems design.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: University; Belgian Lab of Human Computer Interaction; DEA; UCL; Computer Sciences; National Institute of Astrophysics; Computer Sciences; UCL; Louvain School of Management; 	PERSON: Juan Manuel Gonzalez Calleros; Juan Manuel Gonzalez Calleros; 	LOCATION: Louvain; Belgium; Mexico; 	NOUN: Juan Manuel Gonzalez Calleros; Researcher assistant; University catholic; Louvain; UCL; member; Lab; Computer Interaction; UsiXML consortium; scholarship award; Belgium; DEA; computer Science; UCL; master degree; Computer Sciences; National Institute; Astrophysics; Optics; Electronic; Mexico; Juan Manuel Gonzalez Calleros; PhD; Computer Sciences; thesis model Driven engineering; 3D User Interfaces; UCL; Louvain School; Management; IAG-LSM; research interests; workflow models; engineering; User Interfaces; 3D User Interfaces; User Interface; cockpit systems design; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

4f8e5b80e80eb0e487081588 3 10----Bio----#text.P.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	jean:1 cgt:1 bchi:2 lovain:1 tool:1 inria:1 lead:1 valencia:1 ssh:1 level:4 chief:2 coordin:1 work:1 cnica:1 scientif:2 feder:1 involv:1 belgium:1 ist:1 catholiqu:1 project:3 editor:1 co:2 european:3 cast:1 bio:1 chi:1 vanderdonckt:1 professor:2 comput:3 usixml:1 region:1 springer:1 hundr:1 seri:1 guidelin:1 paper:1 universit:1 launch:1 ilsm:1 aid:1 run:1 de:2 author:2 domain:1 current:1 sstc:1 develop:1 initi:2 institut:1 scienc:1 hci:1 invit:1 universidad:1 louvain:3 manag:2 polit:1 research:2 sever:2 human:2 serenoa:1 eg:4 school:2 interfac:1 intern:1 laboratori:1 book:1 interact:2 user:1 design:1	||	Bio:	##true@@false$$	Jean Vanderdonckt is Professor of Computer Science at Louvain School of Management, Universit catholique de Louvain (Belgium) where he leads the Louvain Interaction Laboratory of Computer-Human Interaction (BCHI) and he is an invited professor at Universidad Polit cnica de Valencia. He is chief of the Lovain School of Management Research Institute (	##false@@false$$	SSH	##false@@true$$	ILSM	##false@@true$$	). He is the author or co-author of more than a hundred scientific papers and several books in CHI. In this domain, he launched the initiative on Computer-Aided Design of User Interfaces and Tools for Working with Guidelines. BCHI is currently running several research/development projects at the regional level (e.g., First, Initiative, CGT), federal level (e.g. SSTC), European level (e.g. IST V), and international level (e.g., with INRIA, CAST). He is the scientific coordinator of the European ITEA2 UsiXML project and involved in FP7 Human, FP7 Serenoa European projects. He is co-editor in chief of the Springer HCI Series.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Computer Science; Louvain School of Management; Louvain; Louvain Interaction Laboratory of Computer-Human Interaction; Universidad Polit; Valencia; Lovain School of Management Research Institute; Computer-Aided Design of User Interfaces and Tools; BCHI; CGT; SSTC; 	PERSON: Jean Vanderdonckt; 	LOCATION: Belgium; CHI; 	NOUN: Bio; Jean Vanderdonckt; Professor; Computer Science; Louvain School; Management; Universit; Louvain; Belgium; Louvain Interaction Laboratory; Computer-Human Interaction; BCHI; professor; Universidad Polit; Valencia; chief; Lovain School; Management Research Institute; SSH ILSM; author; co-author; papers; books; CHI; domain; initiative; Computer-Aided Design; User Interfaces; Tools; Guidelines; BCHI; research\/development projects; level; First; Initiative; CGT; level; level; V; level; INRIA; CAST; coordinator; ITEA2 UsiXML project; FP7; FP7 Serenoa European projects; co-editor; chief; Springer HCI Series; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##true@@true$$

4f8e5b6ae80eb0e43a011588 2 9----Bio----#text.A.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	creation:1 heinz:2 complex:1 decis:1 award:1 otto:2 character:1 center:1 presid:1 univers:4 bremen:2 combin:1 busi:1 role:1 serv:1 develop:1 institut:1 dynam:1 scienc:1 bonn:1 founder:1 peitgen:3 futur:1 mathemat:1 cevi:1 career:1 receiv:1 jacob:1 director:1 professorship:1 extraordinarili:1 system:2 visual:1 experi:1 habilit:1 plai:1 ag:1 success:1	||	The career of Jacobs University s future president	##false@@false$$	Heinz-Otto Peitgen	##true@@false$$	is characterized by an extraordinarily successful combination of science and business experience. At the age of 32, Peitgen received his habilitation in Mathematics at the University of Bonn and was then awarded a professorship at the University of Bremen. There, he played a decisive role in the creation and development of the Institute for Dynamic Systems. Since 1992, Heinz-Otto Peitgen served as both, the founder and director of the Center of Complex Systems and Visualization (CeVis) at the	##false@@false$$	University of Bremen	##false@@true$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Jacobs University; University of Bonn; University of Bremen; Institute for Dynamic Systems; Center of Complex Systems and Visualization; University of Bremen; 	PERSON: Heinz-Otto Peitgen; Peitgen; Heinz-Otto Peitgen; 	DATE: 1992; 	NOUN: career; Jacobs University; president Heinz-Otto Peitgen; combination; science; business experience; age; Peitgen; habilitation; Mathematics; University; Bonn; professorship; University; Bremen; role; creation; development; Institute; Dynamic Systems; Heinz-Otto Peitgen; founder; director; Center; Systems; Visualization; CeVis; University; Bremen; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##true@@false$$

In 1997, Peitgen founded a MeVis-spin-off company together with some of his colleagues:	##false@@false$$	MeVis Medical Solutions AG (MMS)	##false@@true$$	has been listed at the German stock market since 2007. MMS is one of the world s leading producers of software products for image-based medicine, particularly for breast and lung cancer diagnosis.
