4f8e5b6ae80eb0e43a011588 0 2----Bio----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	christian:1 fensk:1 phd:1 stabilit:1 asymptot:1 six:1 doctor:1 fix:1 univers:1 econom:1 year:1 institut:1 bonn:2 peitgen:1 work:1 dissert:1 theorem:1 asymptotisch:1 later:1 physic:1 mathemat:2 receiv:1 stabil:1 tze:1 fixpunkt:1 point:1 entitl:1 und:1 appli:1 english:1 studi:1	||	Peitgen studied mathematics, physics and economics from 1965 until 1971 in	##false@@false$$	Bonn	##false@@true$$	, later working for six years at the Institute for Applied Mathematics at the	##false@@false$$	University of Bonn	##false@@true$$	under Christian Fenske, where he received his PhD in 1973. His doctoral dissertation was entitled Asymptotische Fixpunkts tze und Stabilit t (English: Asymptotic Fixed-point Theorems and Stability ).	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Institute for Applied Mathematics; University of Bonn; 	PERSON: Christian Fenske; 	DATE: 1965; 1971; 1973; 	LOCATION: Bonn; 	NOUN: Peitgen; mathematics; physics; economics; Bonn; years; Institute; Applied Mathematics; University; Bonn; Christian Fenske; PhD; dissertation; Asymptotische Fixpunkts tze und Stabilit t; English; Theorems; Stability; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
4f8e5b6ae80eb0e43a011588 0 3----Bio----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	complex:2 graphic:1 set:1 data:1 award:1 center:1 visualisierung:1 univers:2 bremen:2 diagnost:1 deepli:1 serv:1 analysi:3 develop:1 institut:1 bonn:1 dynam:2 founder:1 peitgen:1 work:1 numer:1 privat:1 centrum:1 mathemat:2 docent:1 cevi:1 establish:1 us:1 involv:1 receiv:1 imag:2 director:1 taught:1 research:1 professorship:1 und:1 system:4 visual:1 habilit:1 experi:1 base:1 laboratori:1 emphas:1 comput:2 medic:1	||	After receiving his	##false@@false$$	habilitation	##false@@true$$	in 1977, he first taught as a private docent in Bonn before being awarded a professorship in mathematics at the	##false@@false$$	University of Bremen	##false@@true$$	. There, he was deeply involved in the establishment and development of an Institute for Dynamical Systems, where in 1982 he set up a computer graphics laboratory for mathematical experiments. Since 1992, Peitgen has served as the founder and director of the Center for Complex Systems and Visualization (Centrum f r Complexe Systeme und Visualisierung - CeVis) at the University of Bremen. His research work emphasizes dynamical systems, numerical analysis, image analysis and data analysis, as well as the use of computers in image-based medical diagnostics.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: University of Bremen; Institute for Dynamical Systems; Center for Complex Systems and Visualization; University of Bremen; 	PERSON: Peitgen; 	DATE: 1977; 1982; 1992; 	LOCATION: Bonn; 	NOUN: habilitation; docent; Bonn; professorship; mathematics; University; Bremen; establishment; development; Institute; Dynamical Systems; computer graphics laboratory; experiments; Peitgen; founder; director; Center; Systems; Visualization; r Complexe Systeme und Visualisierung; CeVis; University; Bremen; research work; systems; analysis; image analysis; data analysis; use; computers; diagnostics; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
4f8e5b6ae80eb0e43a011588 0 4----Bio----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	particularli:2 mevi:3 colleagu:1 substanti:1 supervisori:1 lead:1 gmbh:1 therapi:1 center:1 independ:1 stock:1 univers:2 bremen:1 florida:1 diagnost:1 neurolog:1 medicin:1 peitgen:4 screen:1 radiolog:1 california:1 compani:1 german:1 atlant:1 board:1 imag:3 provid:1 breast:1 digit:1 fraunhof:2 market:1 professor:2 comput:2 medic:4 solut:2 chairman:1 call:1 boca:1 becam:1 santa:1 cruz:1 societi:1 valu:1 institut:3 condit:1 softwar:2 intervent:1 mm:2 mathemat:2 manag:1 list:1 produc:1 research:1 begin:1 product:1 lung:1 plan:1 raton:1 practition:1 base:1 ad:1 ag:1 cancer:2 world:1 found:2	||	From 1985 until 1991, Peitgen was a professor of mathematics at the	##false@@false$$	University of California, Santa Cruz	##false@@true$$	; since 1991 he has been a professor of mathematics at	##false@@false$$	Florida Atlantic University	##false@@true$$	in	##false@@false$$	Boca Raton	##false@@true$$	. In 1995, he founded the Center for Medical Image Computing, MeVis Research GmbH, in Bremen, which became a Fraunhofer Society institute at the beginning of 2009 and is now called the Fraunhofer MEVIS - Institute for Medical Image Computing. Peitgen still manages the institute. In 1997, Peitgen and some of his colleagues founded a new company, MeVis Medical Solutions AG, MMS, which has been listed on the German stock market since 2007. MMS is one of the world s leading independent producers of software products for image-based medicine, particularly digital radiology. With its software solutions, it provides medical practitioners with substantial added value in screening and diagnostics as well as therapy and intervention planning for cancer, particularly breast cancer, neurology and lung conditions. Peitgen is the Chairman of the Supervisory Board.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: University of California; Florida Atlantic University; Center for Medical Image Computing; MeVis Research GmbH; Fraunhofer Society; Institute for Medical Image Computing; MeVis Medical Solutions AG; MMS; MMS; Supervisory Board; 	PERSON: Peitgen; Santa Cruz; Peitgen; 	DATE: 1985; 1991; 1991; 1995; 2009; 1997; 2007; 	LOCATION: Boca Raton; Bremen; Fraunhofer MEVIS; 	NOUN: Peitgen; professor; mathematics; University; California; Santa Cruz; professor; mathematics; Florida Atlantic University; Boca Raton; Center; Medical Image Computing; MeVis Research GmbH; Bremen; Fraunhofer Society institute; beginning; Fraunhofer MEVIS; Institute; Medical Image Computing; Peitgen; institute; Peitgen; colleagues; company; MeVis Medical Solutions AG; MMS; stock market; MMS; world; producers; software products; medicine; radiology; software solutions; practitioners; value; screening; diagnostics; therapy; intervention planning; cancer; breast cancer; neurology; lung conditions; Peitgen; Chairman; Supervisory Board; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

He is the author of several award-winning books and films that have helped to publicize fractal geometry and chaos theory around the world and is co-editor of several professional journals with an international readership. The scientific disciplines in which he specializes include mathematics, computer science and medicine: dynamical systems, numerical analysis, fractal geometry, chaos theory, computer graphics, image processing, data analysis and IT support for image-based medical diagnostics and treatment.	##false@@false$$		||	LOCATION: Belgium; Brazil; Canada; USA; Mexico; Italy; 	NOUN: Peitgen; chairs; universities; professor; universities; Belgium; Brazil; Canada; USA; Mexico; Italy; author; books; films; geometry; chaos theory; world; co-editor; journals; readership; disciplines; mathematics; computer science; medicine; systems; analysis; geometry; chaos theory; computer graphics; image processing; data analysis; diagnostics; treatment; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

506d54ae9ccfb0e4e7dec96d 3 2----Others----#text.SPAN.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	chua:1 ee:1 zhu:1 feida:1 freddi:1 lim:1 peng:1	||	Ee-Peng Lim, Feida Zhu, Freddy Chua	##false@@false$$		||	PERSON: Ee-Peng Lim; Feida Zhu; Freddy Chua; 	NOUN: Ee-Peng Lim; Feida Zhu; Freddy Chua; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
506d54ae9ccfb0e4e7dec96d 3 3----Presentation----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	anomali:1 reveal:1 incorpor:1 promin:1 facilit:1 distinct:1 tremend:1 tutori:1 time:1 level:1 interest:1 social:4 rang:1 viral:1 topic:1 number:1 wide:1 inform:3 present:1 discov:1 encod:1 often:1 discuss:1 interperson:1 commun:2 collect:2 critic:1 span:1 model:3 edg:1 can:1 behavior:5 knowledg:1 identif:1 data:2 line:1 insight:1 network:3 character:1 attribut:1 driven:1 longitudin:1 mine:2 sometim:1 leverag:1 direct:1 abstract:1 detect:1 includ:1 rich:1 variou:1 process:1 fact:1 pattern:2 featur:1 interact:2 group:1 user:1	||	Abstract: A distinct feature characterizing social network data is the rich user behavior information presented most prominently as the various interpersonal social interactions. These interactive behavior information, often encoded into attributed directed edges, could collectively reveal tremendous insight into a wide range of social network patterns. In fact, incorporating these behavior information into the modeling and mining process is sometimes critical for discovering knowledge at group and community levels. In this tutorial, we discuss how longitudinal behavior data collected over a time span can be leveraged to facilitate the mining of a number of interesting social network patterns including virality modeling, anomaly detection, off-line community identification and behavior-driven topic modeling.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: feature; network data; user behavior information; interactions; behavior information; edges; insight; range; network patterns; fact; behavior information; modeling; mining process; knowledge; group; community levels; tutorial; behavior data; time span; mining; number; network patterns; virality modeling; detection; community identification; topic modeling; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

He received Ph.D. from the University of Minnesota, Minneapolis in 1994 and B.Sc. in Computer Science from National University of Singapore. His research interests include social network and web mining, information integration, and digital libraries. He is currently an Associate Editor of the ACM Transactions on Information Systems (TOIS), Information Processing and Management (IPM), Social Network Analysis and Mining, Journal of Web Engineering (JWE), IEEE Intelligent Systems, International Journal of Digital Libraries (IJDL) and International Journal of Data Warehousing and Mining (IJDWM). He obtained his Ph.D. in Computer Science from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign (UIUC) in 2009 and his B.Sc. in Computer Science from Fudan University, China, in 2001. His current research interests include large-scale data mining, graph mining and social network analysis. His research on large-scale frequent pattern mining has won the Best Student Paper Awards at 2007 IEEE International Conference on Data Engineering (ICDE) and 2007 Pacific-Asia Conference on Knowledge Discovery and Data Mining (PAKDD). He has served on the Program Committees of PVLDB, ICDE, ICDM, SDM, KDD, DASFAA, SocInfo, ASONAM among others. 506d54ae9ccfb0e4e7dec96d 1 5----Presentation----#text.H4.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	abstract:1	||	Abstract	##true@@false$$		||		||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
506d54ae9ccfb0e4e7dec96d 1 6----Research----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	gener:2 distribut:1 challeng:1 kei:1 weav:1 roll:1 oper:1 interest:1 experiment:1 on:1 effici:4 work:1 provid:1 topolog:3 inform:2 newli:1 queri:3 node:1 materi:1 comput:2 demonstr:1 cube:1 underli:1 propos:3 vari:1 result:1 call:1 give:1 knowledg:1 constraint:2 chosen:1 network:5 kind:1 subset:1 best:1 criteria:1 origin:1 framework:4 handl:1 techniqu:2 monoton:1 achiev:1 process:2 focu:1 effect:2 incur:1 measur:1 certain:1 chang:1 olap:6 user:1 studi:1	||	We propose a framework for efficient OLAP on information networks with a focus on the most interesting kind, the topological OLAP (called T-OLAP ), which incurs topological changes in the underlying networks. T-OLAP operations generate new networks from the original ones by rolling up a subset of nodes chosen by certain constraint criteria. The key challenge is to efficiently compute measures for the newly generated networks and handle user queries with varied constraints. Two effective computational techniques, T-Distributiveness and T-Monotonicity are proposed to achieve efficient query processing and cube materialization. We also provide a T-OLAP query processing framework into which these techniques are weaved. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first work to give a framework study for topological OLAP on information networks. Experimental results demonstrate both the effectiveness and efficiency of our proposed framework.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: OLAP; OLAP; OLAP; 	NOUN: framework; OLAP; information networks; focus; kind; OLAP; T-OLAP; changes; networks; operations; networks; ones; subset; nodes; constraint criteria; challenge; measures; networks; user queries; constraints; techniques; T-Distributiveness; T-Monotonicity; query processing; cube materialization; T-OLAP query processing framework; techniques; knowledge; work; framework study; OLAP; information networks; results; effectiveness; efficiency; framework; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

4f8e5b81e80eb0e45c091588 2 4----Bio----#text.P.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	verif:1 model:1 concurr:2 paper:1 state:1 universit:1 net:1 automat:1 foundat:2 stochast:1 contribut:1 munich:1 author:1 infinit:1 develop:1 analysi:2 publish:1 theoret:1 scienc:1 softwar:1 nchen:1 held:1 check:1 previous:1 petri:1 scientif:1 javier:1 techniqu:1 field:1 system:1 co:1 technisch:1 edinburgh:1 esparza:1 program:3 reliabl:1 professor:1 book:1 comput:1 stuttgart:1 theori:2 lectur:1 posit:1	||	About the lecturer:	##true@@false$$	Javier Esparza is Professor for Foundations of Software Reliability and Theoretical Computer Science at the Technische Universit t M nchen. Previously he held positions in Edinburgh, Munich, and Stuttgart. He has co-authored two books and has published about 100 scientific papers in the fields of automatic program verification, program analysis, and concurrency theory. He has contributed to the theory of Petri nets and to the foundations of program analysis, and has developed model-checking techniques for concurrent, infinite-state, and stochastic systems.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Foundations of Software Reliability and Theoretical Computer Science; Technische Universit; 	PERSON: Javier Esparza; 	LOCATION: Edinburgh; Munich; Stuttgart; 	NOUN: lecturer; Javier Esparza; Professor; Foundations; Software Reliability; Computer Science; Technische Universit t M nchen; positions; Edinburgh; Munich; Stuttgart; books; papers; fields; program verification; program analysis; concurrency theory; theory; Petri nets; foundations; program analysis; techniques; infinite-state; systems; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
4f8e5b81e80eb0e45c091588 2 5----Others----#text.P.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	model:1 can:1 infin:1 state:2 cours:1 simplest:1 possibl:1 constraint:1 roughli:1 space:2 mai:1 infinit:1 finit:2 focus:1 analysi:1 softwar:1 prove:1 check:1 classifi:1 begin:1 system:2 summari:1 larg:1 appropri:1 hardwar:1 sourc:1 group:1	||	Course summary:	##true@@false$$	In its beginnings, model-checking focused on the analysis of systems with a possibly large but finite state space. However, while the finiteness constraint has proved to be very appropriate for hardware, even the simplest software systems may have an infinite state space. The sources of infinity can be roughly classified into three groups:	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: Course summary; beginnings; analysis; systems; state space; finiteness constraint; hardware; software systems; state space; sources; infinity; groups; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

4f8e5b6ae80eb0e4a1011588 1 10----Bio----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	phd:1 visit:2 germani:1 scientist:1 electr:3 ny:1 faculti:1 center:1 munich:2 height:1 univers:6 texa:1 year:1 colleg:1 work:1 control:1 station:1 ibm:1 assist:1 nation:1 degre:2 system:1 professor:5 commun:1 runyon:1 yorktown:1 watson:1 engin:3 data:1 becam:1 associ:1 thoma:1 spent:1 hawaii:2 protocol:1 technic:1 rice:1 error:1 lin:1 bsee:1 taiwan:2 houston:1 taipei:1 ms:1 honolulu:1 return:1 receiv:1 join:2 research:1 shu:1 tx:1 irma:1 chair:2 academ:1 respect:1	||	Shu Lin received the B.S.E.E. degree from the National Taiwan University, Taipei, Taiwan, in 1959, and the M.S. and Ph.D. degrees in electrical engineering from Rice University, Houston, TX, in 1964 and 1965, respectively. In 1965, he joined the Faculty of the University of Hawaii, Honolulu, as an Assistant Professor of Electrical Engineering. He became an Associate Professor in 1969 and a Professor in 1973. In 1986, he joined Texas A&M University, College Station, as the Irma Runyon Chair Professor of Electrical Engineering. In 1987, he returned to the University of Hawaii. From 1978 to 1979, he was a Visiting Scientist at the IBM Thomas J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY, where he worked on error control protocols for data communication systems. He spent the academic year of 1996-1997 as a Visiting Chair Professor at the Technical University of Munich, Munich, Germany.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: B.S.E.E.; National Taiwan University; M.S.; Rice University; University of Hawaii; Texas A&M University; University of Hawaii; IBM Thomas J. Watson Research Center; Yorktown Heights; NY; error control protocols; data communication systems; year; Chair Professor; Technical University; Munich; Munich; Germany; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

He obtained his Ph.D. in Artificial Intelligence in 2005 at the same university, graduating on a project in the area of cognitive modelling. He served as President (2007-2009) and Advisory Board Chair (2009-2011) of Association for Computational Linguistics and Chinese Language Processing (ACLCLP), and Chair (2011-2013) of SIGHAN, a Special Interest Group of the Association for Computational Linguistics. He was also Editorial Board member (2000-2008) of International Journal of Computational Linguistics and Chinese Language Processing, an Associate Editor (2007-2010) of ACM Transactions on Asian Language Information Processing, and an Editor of Journal of Information Science and Engineering (2010-). He was program co-chair of ACM SIGIR 2010, program co-chair of ICADL 2012, served as steering committee members of CLEF and AIRS, senior PC members of ACM SIGIR 2006, 2007, 2008 and 2009, area/track chairs of ACL 2012, ACL-IJCNLP 2009 and ACM CIKM 2008, and PC members of many conferences (IJCAI, SIGIR, AIRS, ACL, COLING, EMNLP, NAACL, IJCNLP, WWW, and so on). He was one of organizers of CLIR, CLQA and MOAT tasks in NTCIR. 4f8e5b6be80eb0e4d5011588 3 4----Bio----#text.P.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.BODY.HTML.#document	phd:1 depart:1 econometr:1 universit:1 bs:1 lian:1 center:1 de:1 northwestern:1 oper:2 univers:3 associ:2 promot:1 institut:1 wen:1 scienc:1 work:1 taiwan:1 mathemat:1 louvain:1 ms:1 assist:1 belgium:1 receiv:2 join:2 catholiqu:1 research:4 nation:1 inform:1 tenur:1 hsu:1 professor:2 core:1 fellow:1 respect:1 cornel:1	||	Wen-Lian Hsu received a B.S. from the Department of Mathematics, National Taiwan University in 1973. He received an M.S. and a Ph.D. in operations research from Cornell University in 1978 and 1980, respectively. From 1979 to 1980, he worked as a research associate in the Center for Operations Research and Econometrics (CORE) at Universite Catholique de Louvain, Belgium. In 1980, he joined Northwestern University as an assistant professor and was promoted to tenured associate professor in 1986. He joined the Institute of Information Science as a research fellow in 1989.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Department of Mathematics; National Taiwan University; M.S.; Cornell University; Center for Operations Research and Econometrics; Universite Catholique de Louvain; Northwestern University; Institute of Information Science; 	PERSON: Wen-Lian Hsu; 	DATE: 1973; 1978; 1980; 1979; 1980; 1980; 1986; 1989; 	LOCATION: Belgium; 	NOUN: Hsu; B.S.; Department; Mathematics; National Taiwan University; M.S.; Ph.D.; operations research; Cornell University; research associate; Center; Operations Research; Econometrics; CORE; Universite Catholique; Louvain; Belgium; Northwestern University; professor; professor; Institute; Information Science; research fellow; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##true@@true$$
4f8e5b6be80eb0e4d5011588 3 5----Research----#text.P.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.BODY.HTML.#document	meantim:1 appear:1 siam:1 structur:2 data:1 recent:1 biologi:1 algorithm:3 tackl:1 contribut:1 northwestern:1 graph:5 tree:1 dna:1 univers:1 invent:1 protein:1 sequenc:1 planar:1 focus:1 analysi:1 effici:1 perfect:1 toler:1 similar:1 dr:1 error:1 class:1 problem:1 research:1 techniqu:1 main:1 appli:1 earlier:1 predict:1 intersect:2 pc:1 comput:2 special:1 public:1 design:1 jacm:1	||	Dr. Hsu's earlier research while in Northwestern University is focused on graph algorithms. His main contribution is on perfect graphs and special classes of intersection graphs. Most of his publications appear in JACM and SIAM J. Computing. Recently, he invented the PC-tree data structure to design very efficient algorithms in planar graphs and intersection graphs. In the meantime, he has applied similar techniques to tackle computational problems in Biology such as error-tolerant algorithms in DNA sequence analysis, protein structure prediction.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Northwestern University; 	PERSON: Dr. Hsu; 	NOUN: Dr. Hsu; research; Northwestern University; graph algorithms; contribution; graphs; classes; intersection graphs; publications; JACM; SIAM J. 4f8e5b6be80eb0e4d5011588 3 6----Research----#text.P.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.BODY.HTML.#document	ten:1 intellig:3 natur:1 languag:2 download:1 chines:4 close:2 hit:1 chen:1 sequenc:1 right:1 move:1 work:1 station:1 genom:1 select:1 resolv:1 number:1 wide:1 agent:2 solv:1 cooper:1 project:2 input:2 system:3 ratio:1 aim:1 pc:1 comput:1 internet:1 go:1 computer:1 result:1 home:1 knowledg:2 phonet:1 dna:1 current:1 best:1 skbot:1 analysi:1 initi:1 institut:1 major:1 softwar:2 manag:1 taiwan:2 later:1 us:1 web:1 produc:1 problem:1 join:1 research:1 achiev:1 product:1 math:1 bottleneck:1 base:1 method:1	||	Right after joining the institute in 1989, he initiated the project ``intelligent Chinese phonetic input system'' (in cooperation with K. J, Chen), aiming at resolving a major bottleneck in the computerization of Chinese language -- the input method. A software resulted from this project, (GOING), achieved a hit ratio close to 96% and was selected as one of the ten best Chinese computer products of Taiwan in 1993. This software has been widely used in Taiwan and the number of downloads in PC Home web station is close to 600,000. Later, he moved into the research of Intelligent Agent on the Internet, and produced the Math. Problem Solving Agent in 1997, and a Chinese natural language Q & A system, @skbots, in 1999. He is currently working on DNA sequence analysis, Genome knowledge base and intelligent knowledge management systems.	##false@@false$$		||	DATE: 1989; 1993; 1997; 1999; 	LOCATION: Chinese; Taiwan; Taiwan; Chinese; 	NOUN: institute; project; input system; cooperation; K. 4f8e5b6be80eb0e4d5011588 3 7----Award----#text.P.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.BODY.HTML.#document	intellig:1 award:2 natur:1 languag:1 council:1 foundat:1 confer:2 contribut:1 oper:1 cocoon:1 recipi:1 follow:1 elect:1 letter:1 involv:1 nation:1 li:1 inform:2 system:1 editor:1 editorship:1 hsu:2 distinguish:2 comput:2 fellow:1 lectur:1 nsc:1 artifici:1 discret:1 notch:1 journal:4 presid:1 societi:1 publish:1 scienc:4 dr:2 top:1 invit:1 taiwan:1 mathemat:1 manag:1 variou:1 receiv:1 research:4 breakthrough:1 process:2 chair:1 intern:2 deliv:1 isaac:1	||	Dr. Hsu has published in various top-notch journals in discrete mathematics, operations research and computer science. He has been invited to deliver lectures in many international conferences. Dr. Hsu received the distinguished research award from the National Science Council in 1991, 1994, 1996 and was elected as a distinguished research fellow by the NSC in 1998. He was the recipient of the first K. T. Li Research Breakthrough Award for his contribution in natural language processing systems. He has been the conference chairs of ISAAC'91 and COCOON'98 and has been involved in the editorship of the following journals: Managing Editor of Journal of Information Science (1995-2001), International Journal of Foundation of Computer Science (1993-2002), Information Processing Letters (2001-). He has been the president of the Artificial Intelligence Society in Taiwan (2001-2002).	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: National Science Council; NSC; K. T. Together with his thesis advisor,	##false@@false$$	Jeffrey Ullman	##false@@true$$	, and fellow Princeton students, including	##false@@false$$	Alberto O. Mendelzon	##false@@true$$	and	##false@@false$$	Yeshoshua Sagiv	##false@@true$$	, he co-authored a number of influential papers that laid out the fundamental issues and approaches for relational databases. In a now-famous paper (Maier, Mendelzon and Sagiv, TODS 1979), he introduced the chase, a method for testing implication of data dependencies that is now of widespread use in the database theory literature.	##false@@false$$	This work has been highly influential: it is used, directly or indirectly, on an everyday basis by people who design databases, and it is used in commercial systems to reason about the consistency and correctness of a data design. New applications of the chase in meta-data management and data exchange are still being discovered.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Princeton; Mendelzon; 	PERSON: Maier; Jeffrey Ullman; Alberto O. 4f8e5b80e80eb0e459081588 1 7----Bio----#text.SPAN.SPAN.SPAN.P.SPAN.SPAN.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.DIV.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.PLACEHOLDER.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.FORM.BODY.HTML.#document	phd:2 cum:1 visit:2 imperi:1 industri:1 council:1 foundat:1 financ:1 fuch:1 interest:1 social:1 cambridg:2 youngest:1 recipi:1 california:1 art:1 hold:2 wolfson:1 ieee:1 system:2 london:1 pretoria:1 professor:1 bachelor:1 harvard:2 western:1 fellow:2 born:1 successfulli:1 engin:9 applic:1 limpopo:1 presid:1 associ:1 publish:1 institut:2 scienc:5 complet:1 member:2 post:1 previous:1 research:5 master:2 chair:2 mechan:1 south:4 reflect:1 world:1 scholar:1 twa:1 intellig:1 award:2 patent:1 dst:1 electr:1 doctor:1 carl:1 supervis:1 student:1 univers:7 dean:1 busi:1 medicin:1 academi:3 colleg:2 follow:1 control:1 scientif:1 witwatersrand:1 nation:1 program:1 emili:1 distinguish:1 comput:2 case:1 senior:1 african:2 johannesburg:1 paper:1 marwala:1 strateg:1 author:1 laud:1 order:1 full:1 reserv:1 societi:1 develop:2 mapungubw:2 africa:2 nrf:1 magna:1 includ:1 acm:1 leadership:1 tshilidzi:1 school:1 royal:1 book:1 venda:1 refere:1 berkelei:1	||	Tshilidzi Marwala born in Venda (Limpopo, South Africa) is the Dean of Engineering at the University of Johannesburg. He was previously a Full Professor of Electrical Engineering, the Carl and Emily Fuchs Chair of Systems and Control Engineering, as well as the DST/NRF South Africa Research Chair of Systems Engineering at the University of the Witwatersrand. He is a Fellow of the following institutions: Royal Society of Arts, the Council for Scientific and Industrial Research, South African Academy of Engineering, South African Academy of Science, TWAS - The Academy of Science of the Developing World and Mapungubwe Institute of Strategic Reflection. He is a senior member of the IEEE and distinguished member of the ACM. He is the youngest recipient of the Order of Mapungubwe and was awarded the President Award by the National Research Foundation. He holds a Bachelor of Science in Mechanical Engineering (Magna Cum Laude) from Case Western Reserve University, a Master of Engineering from the University of Pretoria, a Ph.D. in Engineering from the University of Cambridge and completed a Program for Leadership Development at Harvard Business School. He was a post-doctoral research associate at Imperial College (London) and was a visiting fellow at Harvard University, Wolfson College (Cambridge) and a Visiting Scholar at the University of California (Berkeley). His research interests include the application of computational intelligence to engineering, computer science, finance, social science and medicine. He has successfully supervised 35 masters and 6 PhD students, published over 200 refereed papers, holds 3 patents and authored 3 books.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: University of Johannesburg; Emily Fuchs Chair of Systems and Control Engineering; South Africa Research Chair of Systems Engineering; University of the Witwatersrand; Royal Society of Arts; Council for Scientific and Industrial Research; South African Academy of Engineering; South African Academy of Science; South Africa; London; Cambridge; Berkeley; 	NOUN: Tshilidzi Marwala; Venda; Limpopo; South Africa; Dean; Engineering; University; Johannesburg; Professor; Engineering; Carl; Emily Fuchs Chair; Systems; 4f8e5b81e80eb0e412091588 2 4----Research----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.SECTION.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	integr:2 understand:1 proven:1 besid:1 impact:1 open:1 time:1 inc:1 search:1 import:1 focus:1 deep:2 work:2 topic:1 form:1 creat:2 compani:1 scientif:4 involv:1 discoveri:1 workflow:1 extract:1 inform:2 co:2 system:1 visual:1 start:1 emerg:1 sourc:1 known:1 span:1 deeppeeporg:1 scale:1 creation:1 engin:1 data:3 applic:2 introduc:1 document:1 current:1 best:1 york:1 serv:1 mine:1 develop:1 dr:1 site:1 includ:2 entri:1 manag:3 theme:1 crawl:1 freir:1 web:4 problem:1 vistrail:2 research:3 technolog:1 sever:1 point:1 led:1 address:1 retriev:1 larg:1 featur:1 cluster:1 special:1 within:1 group:1 found:1	||	An important theme in her research is the development of data management technology to address new problems introduced by emerging applications, including the Web and scientific applications. Her current research involves the understanding, integration and management of large-scale data. Within scientific data management, she is best known for her work in provenance, scientific workflows and visualization, and for co-creating the open-source VisTrails system. Besides its scientific impact, this work has also led to the creation of VisTrails, Inc., a start-up company she co-founded. In Web mining, Dr. Freire s research has spanned several topics, including focused crawling, document clustering, deep-Web information discovery and retrieval, information extraction and integration. Her group created DeepPeep.org, a search engine specialized in forms that serve as entry points to deep Web sites, which was featured in the New York Times.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: VisTrails , Inc.; New York Times; 	PERSON: Dr. Freire; 	NOUN: theme; research; development; data management technology; problems; applications; Web; applications; research; understanding; integration; management; data; data management; work; provenance; workflows; visualization; open-source VisTrails system; impact; work; creation; VisTrails; Inc.; company; Web mining; Dr. Freire; research; topics; crawling; document clustering; information discovery; retrieval; information extraction; integration; group; DeepPeep.org; search engine; forms; entry points; Web sites; New York Times; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

He received his B.A. degree in mathematics, and his Ph.D. degree in computer science from Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences,	##false@@false$$	New York University	##false@@true$$	. He is currently the Richard and Loan Hill Professor of	##false@@false$$	Computer Science	##false@@true$$	at the	##false@@false$$	University of Illinois at Chicago	##false@@true$$	, and an Affiliate Professor in the	##false@@false$$	Department of Computer Science at the University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign	##false@@true$$	. He is the founder of Mobitrac, a high-tech startup that was acquired by Fluensee Co. in 2006; and the founder and president of Pirouette Software Inc. which specializes in mobile data management. He served as a consultant to Argonne National Laboratory, US Army Research Laboratories, DARPA, and NASA. Before joining the University of Illinois he has been on the computer science faculty at the Technion and Columbia University, and a Member of Technical Staff at Bell Laboratories.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: B.A.; Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences; New York University; Loan Hill Professor of Computer Science; University of Illinois; Department of Computer Science; University of Illinois; Fluensee Co.; Pirouette Software Inc.; Argonne National Laboratory; US Army Research Laboratories; DARPA; NASA; University of Illinois; Columbia University; Bell Laboratories; 	PERSON: Ouri Wolfson; Richard; 	DATE: 2006; 	LOCATION: Chicago; Urbana Champaign; Mobitrac; 	NOUN: Biographical sketch; Ouri Wolfson; research interests; database systems; systems; computing; B.A. degree; mathematics; Ph.D. degree; computer science; Courant Institute; Mathematical Sciences; New York University; Richard; Loan Hill Professor; Computer Science; University; Illinois; Chicago; Affiliate Professor; Department; Computer Science; University; Illinois; Urbana Champaign; founder; Mobitrac; startup; Fluensee Co.; founder; president; Pirouette Software Inc.; data management; consultant; Argonne National Laboratory; US Army Research Laboratories; DARPA; NASA; University; Illinois; computer science faculty; Technion; Columbia University; Member; Technical Staff; Bell Laboratories; 	||	##true@@true$$	||	##false@@false$$

4f8e5b81e80eb0e40e091588 0 4----Bio----#text.A.P.BODY.HTML.#document	phd:1 nasa:1 grant:1 gener:2 lead:1 foundat:2 defens:1 confer:3 fund:1 mobil:1 scientif:1 board:1 nation:1 nato:1 wolfson:1 inform:1 project:1 co:2 system:1 editori:1 ouri:1 disciplin:1 gi:1 advanc:2 hugh:1 program:1 nsf:2 comput:1 air:1 mdm:1 princip:1 informix:1 agenc:1 armi:1 data:1 state:1 geograph:1 recent:1 journal:1 transport:1 current:1 serv:1 york:1 sigspati:1 forc:1 scienc:3 accentur:1 acm:2 manag:1 establish:1 afosr:1 us:1 research:4 technolog:1 sever:1 chair:3 hitachi:1 offic:1 darpa:1 intern:1 laboratori:1 investig:1	||	Ouri Wolfson serves on the editorial boards of several journals, and chaired leading conferences. Wing is the President's Professor of Computer Science in the Computer Science Department at Carnegie Mellon University. She received her S.B. and S.M. degrees in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science in 1979 and her Ph.D. degree in Computer Science in 1983, all from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. From 2004-2007, she was Head of the Computer Science Department at Carnegie Mellon. 4f8e5b6ae80eb0e4b5011588 4 5----Research----#text.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	need:1 progress:1 understand:2 defect:1 type:1 uncov:1 reus:1 cover:1 help:2 personnel:1 report:1 proceed:1 repositori:2 support:2 effort:1 describ:1 avail:1 inform:1 project:3 present:1 system:3 aspect:1 visual:1 zusammenfassung:1 commun:1 sourc:2 novel:1 valid:1 model:1 empir:1 idea:1 can:1 data:1 coupl:1 recent:1 evolut:2 version:1 mine:2 develop:4 analysi:1 fine:1 talk:1 softwar:8 manag:1 rich:1 track:1 variou:1 us:1 analyz:1 research:1 potenti:1 exploit:1 techniqu:2 artifact:1 great:1 pattern:1 archiv:1 plan:1 predict:1 grain:1 base:1 bug:1 improv:1 wai:1 chang:2 evolutionari:1 modif:1 design:1	||	Zusammenfassung	##true@@false$$	Software repositories such as versioning systems, defect tracking systems, and archived communication between project personnel are used to help manage the progress of software projects. There is great potential in mining this information to support the evolution of software systems, improve software design or reuse, and empirically validate novel ideas and techniques. Research is now proceeding to uncover ways in which mining these repositories can help to understand software development, to support predictions about software development, and to plan various evolutionary aspects of software projects. This talk presents some analysis and visualization techniques to understand software evolution by exploiting the rich sources of artifacts that are available. Based on the data models, that need to be developed to cover sources such as modification and bug reports, we describe some of our recent efforts to analyze developer patterns, change couplings, and fine-grained change types.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: Zusammenfassung Software repositories; systems; defect tracking systems; communication; project personnel; progress; software projects; potential; mining; information; evolution; software systems; software design; reuse; ideas; techniques; Research; ways; mining; repositories; software development; predictions; software development; aspects; software projects; talk; analysis; visualization techniques; software evolution; sources; artifacts; data models; need; sources; modification; bug reports; efforts; developer patterns; change couplings; change types; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##true@@false$$
4f8e5b6ae80eb0e4b5011588 4 6----Bio----#text.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	phd:1 zurich:1 servic:1 distribut:1 esec:1 reengin:1 symposium:1 foundat:1 prior:1 confer:2 univers:3 interest:1 focus:1 msr:1 repositori:1 workshop:1 qualiti:1 avail:1 inform:1 system:2 european:1 http:1 program:1 harald:1 professor:2 centric:1 austria:1 techn:1 coloc:1 gall:2 ics:1 depart:1 engin:6 vortragend:1 recent:1 evolut:1 vienna:2 sigsoft:1 collabor:1 associ:1 switzerland:1 mine:1 analysi:1 dr:1 msc:1 softwar:11 technic:2 includ:1 acm:1 fse:1 receiv:1 research:1 chair:1 informat:2 architectur:1 intern:2 group:1 sealifiuzhch:1	||	Vortragender	##true@@false$$	Harald C. Gall is a professor of software engineering in the Department of Informatics at the University of Zurich, Switzerland. Prior to that, he was an associate professor in the Distributed Systems Group at the Technical University of Vienna. He received the MSc and PhD (Dr. techn.) in informatics from the Technical University of Vienna, Austria. His research interests include software engineering, focusing on software evolution, software quality analysis, software architecture, reengineering, collaborative software engineering, and service centric software systems. Recently, he was the program chair of the European Software Engineering Conference and the ACM SIGSOFT Symposium on the Foundations of Software Engineering (ESEC-FSE) in 2005, the International Workshop on Mining Software Repositories (MSR), colocated with the International Conference on Software Engineering (ICSE) in 2006 and 2007. More information is available at http://seal.ifi.uzh.ch/gall.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Department of Informatics; University of Zurich; Distributed Systems Group; Technical University of Vienna; MSc; Technical University of Vienna; European Software Engineering Conference; International Conference on Software Engineering; 	PERSON: Harald C. 362490-2 4 5----Research----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	virtual:1 integr:1 convent:1 natur:1 multimod:1 mous:1 complement:1 altern:1 read:1 analysi:1 develop:1 especi:1 displai:1 gestur:1 control:1 keyboard:1 includ:1 audio:1 lip:1 vision:1 environ:1 recognit:2 us:2 accuraci:1 research:1 techniqu:1 human:1 project:1 speech:3 visual:2 effect:1 interfac:2 base:1 comput:1 interact:1 enhanc:1	||	Multimodal	##false@@false$$	human computer interaction	##false@@true$$	, especially the use of speech- and vision-based techniques in developing more natural and effective interfaces as alternatives to complements of conventional interfaces such as the keyboard and the mouse. Research projects include the integration of	##false@@false$$	speech recognition	##false@@true$$	and visual gesture analysis in controlling display in virtual environments; and the use of visual lip reading to enhance audio speech recognition accuracy.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: computer interaction; use; speech; techniques; interfaces; alternatives; interfaces; keyboard; mouse; Research projects; integration; speech recognition; gesture analysis; display; environments; use; lip; speech recognition accuracy; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
362490-2 4 6----Research----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	virtual:1 need:1 face:1 anim:1 model:4 phone:1 idea:1 tool:1 space:1 applic:1 hand:1 esp:1 obvious:1 sent:1 sequenc:1 drive:1 electron:1 movement:1 develop:1 synthesi:1 analysi:1 video:3 end:4 transmit:2 bitrat:1 origin:1 conferenc:1 problem:1 us:1 receiv:2 game:1 code:1 avatar:1 research:1 extract:1 human:1 inform:2 bodi:1 regener:1 scenario:2 base:1 teleconferenc:1 construct:1 low:1 user:1 motiv:1	||	3-D modeling, analysis, and synthesis (animation) of human face, hands, and body. The original motivation for this research is very low bitrate 3-D model-based video coding, esp. for video phone and teleconferencing scenarios. The idea is that if a 3-D model of the user at the transmitting end is constructed at the receiving end, then only the movement information needs to be extracted at the transmitting end and sent to the receiving end, where this information is used to drive the 3-D model and to regenerate the video sequence. Obviously, the tools developed for these scenarios are applicable to many other problems, such as virtual space conferencing with avatars, and electronic games.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: modeling; analysis; synthesis; animation; face; hands; body; motivation; research; bitrate; video coding; esp; video phone; teleconferencing scenarios; idea; model; user; end; end; movement information; end; end; information; model; video sequence; tools; scenarios; problems; space; avatars; games; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

Of special interest are the use of	##false@@false$$	relevance feedback	##false@@true$$	in adapting the databases system to user intentions (when browsing or searching), and the construction of a table of contents and a semantic index for video using multimedia information (image sequence, audio, and closed-captions if available).	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: Multimedia; images; video; audio; text; databases; content; image retrieval; interest; use; relevance feedback; databases system; user intentions; construction; table; contents; index; video; multimedia information; image sequence; audio; closed-captions; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

Dr. Huang’s work includes collaborations with colleagues around the world, including work with Dr. Arun Netravali of Lucent Technologies’ Bell Labs. Together they have produced a number of papers which have inspired significant work in both industry and academia. Among the first to tackle digital image-processing research, they have solved many of the key problems of video processing.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Lucent Technologies Bell Labs; 	PERSON: Dr. Huang; Dr. Huangs; Dr. Arun Netravali; 	LOCATION: academia; 	NOUN: career; images; Dr. Huang; contributions; holography; compression; documents; coding; images; 3D motion analysis; interface; image\/video databases; Dr. Huangs work; collaborations; colleagues; world; work; Dr. Arun Netravali; Lucent Technologies Bell Labs; number; papers; work; industry; academia; research; problems; video processing; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##true@@true$$

406605-4 12 6----Bio----#text.SPAN.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.FORM.BODY.HTML.#document	william:1 illinoi:1 servic:1 award:1 perform:1 electr:1 faculti:1 urbana:1 contribut:3 univers:1 interest:2 event:1 colleg:2 elect:1 textbook:1 inaugur:1 awarde:1 dartmouth:1 wide:1 mari:1 director:1 inform:1 ieee:1 co:1 system:1 simul:3 professor:1 comput:2 distinguish:1 david:1 fellow:2 posit:1 discret:1 model:1 engin:1 champaign:1 author:1 area:1 analysi:1 institut:1 held:1 includ:1 previous:1 acm:2 trust:1 us:1 teach:1 research:2 field:1 secur:1 nicol:1 special:1 group:1	||	David M. Nicol is Professor of Computer and Electrical Engineering at the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign, and Director of the Information Trust Institute.   Previously he held faculty positions at the College of William and Mary, and Dartmouth College.   His research interests include high performance computing, simulation modeling and analysis, and security.   He was elected Fellow of the IEEE, and Fellow of the ACM for his contributions in these areas.   He is co-author of the widely used textbook "Discrete-Event Systems Simulation", and was the inaugural awardee of the ACM Special Interest Group on Simulation's Distinguished Contributions Award, for his contributions in research, teaching, and service in the field of simulation.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Computer and Electrical Engineering; University of Illinois; Urbana-Champaign; Information Trust Institute; College of William and Mary; Dartmouth College; ACM Special Interest Group on Simulation; 	PERSON: David M. 406605-3 11 2----Others----#text.SPAN.P.BODY.HTML.#document	submiss:1 grant:4 test:1 colleagu:1 servic:2 higher:1 lead:1 juli:1 brentrup:2 mellon:1 foundat:1 collegecadartmouthedu:1 univers:2 oper:1 file:1 request:1 year:1 educ:1 along:1 colleg:1 robert:2 submit:1 lawrenc:1 feder:1 effort:1 dartmouth:2 ist:1 pki:1 health:1 commend:1 provid:1 nation:2 project:1 obtain:1 http:1 professor:1 comput:4 david:1 propos:2 wisconsin:1 deploy:1 ed:2 author:2 associ:1 electron:1 sean:1 august:1 fbca:1 bridg:2 won:2 initi:2 develop:2 institut:1 scienc:2 softwar:1 andrew:1 certif:3 levin:1 hebca:2 particip:1 smith:1 us:1 came:1 join:1 research:1 organ:1 nicol:1 base:1 deploi:1 blueprint:1 group:1 pkilab:1 success:1	||	Ed came to Computer Science from Dartmouth's ISTS which he joined in August 2000. While a Research Associate there, he, Robert J. Brentrup of Computing Services, Professors David M. Nicol and Sean W. Smith of Computer Science submitted a proposal to the Internet2 organization in July 2000 for a PKILab. They won the two year grant along with colleagues at the University of Wisconsin. Based on this initial effort,  the group and Lawrence Levine of Computer Services filed a grant proposal with the Andrew Mellon Foundation to develop and provide software and an operational blueprint for PKI that could be deployed at the nations colleges and universities. They were successful in obtaining this grant that has lead to initial development and deployment at Dartmouth of the Dartmouth Certificate Authority (see http://collegeca.dartmouth.edu).  Robert J. Brentrup and Ed participated in the Higher Education Bridge Certificate Authority's (HEBCA) test of electronic submission of grant requests to the National Institute of Health using the HEBCA and  the Federal Bridge Certificate Authority (FBCA). This project won a commendation.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Computer Science; Dartmouth; Research Associate; Computing Services; Computer Science; University of Wisconsin; Computer Services; Andrew Mellon Foundation; PKI; Dartmouth; Dartmouth Certificate Authority; National Institute of Health; HEBCA; Federal Bridge Certificate Authority; 	PERSON: Robert J. 406605-3 11 3----Others----#text.SPAN.P.BODY.HTML.#document	cours:1 distribut:2 electr:1 prior:1 defens:2 help:1 fred:1 univers:1 oper:1 thompson:1 interest:1 virginia:1 work:1 lawrenc:1 california:1 programm:1 dartmouth:1 ist:1 prime:1 system:3 princeton:1 tenur:1 professor:1 comput:7 cdc:2 fellow:1 alexandria:2 senior:2 princip:1 engin:2 applic:1 ed:1 staff:1 associ:1 sabbat:1 develop:1 institut:3 consult:3 scienc:2 dr:1 member:1 softwar:1 analys:2 technic:2 rice:1 star:1 crai:1 came:1 taught:1 technolog:1 research:4 livermor:1 secur:1 laboratori:1 ida:2 studi:2 divis:1	||	Ed came to Dartmouth ISTS from the Computer and Software Engineering Division of the Institute for Defense Analyses (IDA), Alexandria, Virginia where he was a Research Staff Member with interests in Security and Distributed Systems and Applications. Prior to IDA Alexandria, he worked at Prime Computer as a Principal Technical Consultant, Senior Technical Consultant, and Senior Research Consultant. At Rice University he was a tenured Associate Professor of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science. At the Institute for Defense Analyses in Princeton as a Systems Programmer, he helped develop a distributed operating system for a Cray 1 computer. At Lawrence Livermore Laboratory as a Sabbatical Researcher he studied the CDC STAR 100 computer and the CDC 7600 computers, At the California Institute of Technology as a Research Fellow he taught Computer Science Courses and studied under Dr. Fred Thompson.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Dartmouth; Institute for Defense Analyses; Senior Research Consultant; Rice University; Electrical Engineering and Computer Science; Institute for Defense Analyses; Cray; Lawrence Livermore Laboratory; CDC; CDC; California Institute of Technology as a Research Fellow; Computer Science Courses; 	PERSON: Dr. Fred Thompson; 	LOCATION: Alexandria; Virginia; IDA Alexandria; Princeton; 	NOUN: Ed; Dartmouth ISTS; Computer; Software Engineering Division; Institute; Defense Analyses; IDA; Alexandria; Virginia; Research Staff Member; interests; Security; Systems; Applications; IDA Alexandria; Prime Computer; Principal Technical Consultant; Technical Consultant; Senior Research Consultant; Rice University; Associate Professor; Engineering; Computer Science; Institute; Defense Analyses; Princeton; Systems Programmer; operating system; Cray; computer; Lawrence Livermore Laboratory; Sabbatical Researcher; CDC STAR; computer; CDC; computers; California Institute; Technology; Research Fellow; Computer Science Courses; Dr. Fred Thompson; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##false@@true$$
406605-1 3 1----Others----#text.P.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	phd:1 gtw:1 servic:1 distribut:8 symposium:1 urbana:1 defens:1 regent:1 tutori:1 time:3 given:1 richard:1 fujimoto:2 kit:1 numer:1 california:1 principl:1 feder:1 director:1 degre:2 system:2 ieee:1 editor:2 simul:15 transact:2 advanc:1 professor:1 commun:1 committe:1 mascot:1 depart:1 subject:1 engin:3 data:1 siw:1 analysi:1 publish:1 institut:2 ds:1 scienc:3 dr:1 softwar:1 technic:1 ms:1 receiv:1 us:1 research:1 technolog:1 tech:2 worldwid:1 chair:1 keynot:1 led:2 intern:2 public:1 respect:1 illinoi:1 award:1 lead:2 perform:1 bs:1 electr:1 confer:2 level:1 univers:2 chief:1 interoper:1 workshop:3 georgia:3 interim:1 co:1 definit:1 comput:7 rt:1 biographi:1 execut:1 model:4 paper:1 activ:1 warp:1 journal:2 real:1 area:2 fdk:1 societi:1 serv:2 develop:2 hla:1 telecommun:1 parallel:5 pad:1 includ:2 standard:1 acm:1 manag:1 win:1 sever:3 school:1 address:1 architectur:1 organ:1 articl:1 book:1 berkelei:1 found:2	||	Biography:	##true@@false$$	Dr. Richard Fujimoto is Regents Professor and the founding Chair of the School of Computational Science and Engineering at the Georgia Institute of Technology.  He is also the interim director of the Institute for Data and High Performance Computing at Georgia Tech. He received the Ph.D. and M.S. degrees from the University of California, Berkeley in 1983 and 1980, respectively in Computer Science and Electrical Engineering, and two B.S. degrees from the University of Illinois, Urbana in 1977 and 1978 in Computer Science and Computer Engineering.  He has been an active researcher in the parallel and distributed simulation community since 1985, and has published numerous technical papers on this subject.  His publications include three books and several award-winning articles on parallel and distributed simulation. He led the development of parallel/distributed simulation software systems including the Georgia Tech Time Warp (GTW) simulation executive and the Federated Simulation Development Kit (FDK), both of which have been distributed worldwide.  He has given several keynote addresses and tutorials on parallel and distributed simulation at leading conferences.  He led the definition of the time management services for the High Level Architecture (HLA) for modeling and simulation in the U.S. Department of Defense that has since been standardized by IEEE.  Fujimoto has served as Co-Editor-in-chief of the journal Simulation: Transactions of the Society for Modeling and Simulation International as well as a founding area editor for the ACM Transactions on Modeling and Computer Simulation journal.  He has served on the organizing committees for several leading conferences in the parallel and distributed simulation area such as the Principles for Advanced and Distributed Simulation (PADS) Workshop, the Simulation Interoperability Workshop (SIW), International Symposium on Modeling, Analysis, and Simulation of Computer and Telecommunication Systems (MASCOTS), and Distributed Simulation and Real-Time Workshop (DS-RT).	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: School of Computational Science and Engineering; Georgia Institute of Technology; Institute for Data and High Performance Computing; Georgia Tech; M.S.; University of California; Computer Science and Electrical Engineering; University of Illinois; Computer Science and Computer Engineering; Georgia Tech Time Warp; Federated Simulation Development Kit; U.S. Department of Defense; Society for Modeling and Simulation International; ACM Transactions on Modeling and Computer Simulation; Simulation of Computer; 406605-1 3 6----Bio----#text.P.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	william:1 illinoi:1 servic:1 award:1 perform:1 electr:1 faculti:1 urbana:1 contribut:3 univers:1 interest:2 event:1 colleg:2 elect:1 textbook:1 inaugur:1 awarde:1 dartmouth:1 wide:1 mari:1 director:1 inform:1 ieee:1 co:1 system:1 simul:3 professor:1 distinguish:1 comput:2 david:1 fellow:2 biographi:1 posit:1 discret:1 model:1 engin:1 champaign:1 author:1 area:1 analysi:1 institut:1 held:1 includ:1 previous:1 acm:2 trust:1 us:1 teach:1 research:2 field:1 secur:1 nicol:1 special:1 group:1	||	Biography:	##true@@false$$	David M. Nicol is Professor of Computer and Electrical Engineering at the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign, and Director of the Information Trust Institute. Previously he held faculty positions at the College of William and Mary, and Dartmouth College. His research interests include high performance computing, simulation modeling and analysis, and security. He was elected Fellow of the IEEE, and Fellow of the ACM for his contributions in these areas. He is co-author of the widely used textbook "Discrete-Event Systems Simulation", and was the inaugural awardee of the ACM Special Interest Group on Simulation's Distinguished Contributions Award, for his contributions in research, teaching, and service in the field of simulation.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Computer and Electrical Engineering; University of Illinois; Urbana-Champaign; Information Trust Institute; College of William and Mary; Dartmouth College; ACM Special Interest Group on Simulation; 	PERSON: David M. Nicol; 	NOUN: Biography; David M. Nicol; Professor; Computer; Engineering; University; Illinois; Urbana-Champaign; Director; Information Trust Institute; faculty positions; College; William; Mary; Dartmouth College; research interests; performance computing; simulation modeling; analysis; security; Fellow; IEEE; Fellow; ACM; contributions; areas; co-author; textbook; Discrete-Event Systems Simulation; awardee; ACM; Interest Group; Simulation; Distinguished Contributions Award; contributions; research; teaching; service; field; simulation; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##true@@false$$

467434-2 5 2----Bio----#text.P.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	manipul:1 illinoi:1 phd:1 integr:2 electr:1 narendra:1 urbana:1 sensor:1 univers:2 varieti:1 maryland:1 colleg:1 video:1 coordin:1 multipl:1 descript:1 assist:1 imag:6 extract:1 degre:1 inform:1 visual:1 professor:2 commun:1 comput:3 scene:3 sourc:1 ahuja:1 result:1 structur:1 depart:1 engin:1 navig:1 usa:1 applic:1 champaign:1 realist:1 current:2 analysi:2 synthesi:1 institut:1 scienc:2 willet:1 includ:1 park:1 spatial:1 vision:1 robot:1 receiv:1 us:3 join:1 research:1 beckman:1 represent:1 eg:1 dimension:1 donald:1 biggar:1 laboratori:1 emphas:1 construct:1	||	Narendra Ahuja received his Ph.D. degree in computer science from the University of Maryland, College Park, USA, in 1979. In 1979, he joined the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign as Assistant Professor where he is currently Donald Biggar Willet Professor  in the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, the Beckman Institute, and the Coordinated Science Laboratory.  His current research emphasizes integrated use of multiple image sources of scene information to construct three-dimensional and other descriptions of scenes; the use of integrated image analysis for realistic image synthesis; sensors for computer vision; extraction and representation of spatial structure, e.g., in images and video; and use of the results of image analysis for a variety of applications including visual communication, image manipulation, robotics, and scene navigation.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: University of Maryland; University of Illinois; Urbana-Champaign; Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering; Beckman Institute; Coordinated Science Laboratory; 	PERSON: Narendra Ahuja; Donald Biggar Willet; 	DATE: 1979; 1979; 	LOCATION: USA; 	NOUN: Narendra Ahuja; Ph.D. degree; computer science; University; Maryland; College Park; USA; University; Illinois; Urbana-Champaign; Assistant Professor; Donald Biggar Willet Professor; Department; Computer Engineering; Beckman Institute; Coordinated Science Laboratory; research; use; image sources; scene information; descriptions; scenes; use; image analysis; image synthesis; sensors; computer vision; extraction; representation; structure; images; video; use; results; image analysis; variety; applications; communication; image manipulation; robotics; scene navigation; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##true@@false$$
467434-2 5 3----Bio----#text.P.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	understand:1 intellig:3 award:1 electr:2 iee:1 wilei:1 sequenc:1 import:1 motion:1 int:1 recognit:2 kluwer:1 imag:5 board:1 inform:1 ieee:4 co:2 editori:1 machin:1 system:1 transact:2 advanc:2 machineri:1 comput:2 emanuel:1 fellow:1 artifici:2 face:1 press:1 model:1 graphic:1 springer:1 structur:1 engin:3 issu:1 coeditor:1 applic:1 journal:5 author:1 japan:1 associ:4 american:2 societi:1 electron:2 analysi:2 institut:1 gestur:1 scienc:2 vision:3 mathemat:1 edit:1 receiv:1 technolog:2 verlag:1 process:1 pattern:4 book:2 intern:2 guest:1 special:1 pior:1 optic:1	||	He has co-authored the books	##false@@false$$	Pattern Models	##false@@false$$	(Wiley, 1983),	##false@@false$$	Motion and Structure from Image Sequences	##false@@false$$	(Springer-Verlag, 1992), and	##false@@false$$	Face and Gesture Recognition	##false@@false$$	(Kluwer, 2001); and co-edited the book	##false@@false$$	Advances in Image Understanding	##false@@false$$	(IEEE Press, 1996). He is a fellow of IEEE, American Association for Artificial Intelligence, International Association for Pattern Recognition, Association for Computing Machinery, American Association for the Advancement of Science, and International Society for Optical Engineering. He is on the editorial boards of the journals IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence; Computer Vision, Graphics, and Image Processing; Journal of Mathematical Imaging and Vision; Journal of Pattern Analysis and Applications; Int. Journal of Imaging Systems and Technology; IEE Japan Transactions on Electrical and Electronic Engineering; and Journal of Information Science and Technology, and a guest coeditor of the Artificial Intelligence Journal's special issue on vision. 467434-2 0 12----Bio----#text.P.DIV.DIV.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	manipul:1 phd:1 illinoi:1 integr:1 govern:1 birla:1 electr:2 narendra:1 urbana:1 distinct:1 sensor:1 pilani:1 univers:3 maryland:2 focus:1 colleg:2 video:1 be:1 coordin:1 multipl:1 bangalor:1 honor:1 scientif:1 recognit:1 imag:3 extract:1 inform:1 degre:3 visual:1 professor:1 scene:1 comput:4 commun:2 sourc:1 ahuja:1 structur:1 depart:2 engin:3 usa:1 applic:1 delhi:1 champaign:1 electron:2 current:2 me:1 india:3 institut:3 scienc:4 willet:1 includ:1 park:2 spatial:1 vision:2 indian:1 us:1 receiv:1 technolog:1 research:1 beckman:1 represent:2 versatil:1 donald:1 retriev:1 offic:1 biggar:1 base:1 laboratori:2	||	Narendra Ahuja received the B.E. degree with honors in electronics engineering from the Birla Institute of Technology and Science, Pilani, India, in 1972, the M.E. degree with distinction in electrical communication engineering from the Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India, in 1974, and the Ph.D. degree in computer science from the University of Maryland, College Park, USA, in 1979. From 1974 to 1975 he was Scientific Officer in the Department of Electronics, Government of India, New Delhi.  From 1975 to 1979 he was at the Computer Vision Laboratory, University of Maryland, College Park. Since 1979 he has been with the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign where he is currently Donald Biggar Willet Professor in the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, the Beckman Institute, and the Coordinated Science Laboratory.  His current research is focused on extraction and representation of spatial structure in images and video; integrated use of multiple image-based sources for scene representation and recognition; versatile sensors for computer vision; and applications including visual communication, image manipulation, and information retrieval.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: B.E.; Birla Institute of Technology and Science; M.E.; Indian Institute of Science; University of Maryland; Department of Electronics; University of Maryland; University of Illinois; Urbana-Champaign; Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering; Beckman Institute; Coordinated Science Laboratory; 	PERSON: Narendra Ahuja; Pilani; Donald Biggar Willet; 	DATE: 1972; 1974; 1979; 1974; 1975; 1975; 1979; 1979; 	LOCATION: India; Bangalore; India; USA; India; New Delhi; 	NOUN: Narendra Ahuja; B.E. degree; honors; electronics engineering; Birla Institute; Technology; Science; Pilani; India; M.E. degree; distinction; communication engineering; Indian Institute; Science; Bangalore; India; Ph.D. degree; computer science; University; Maryland; College Park; USA; Scientific Officer; Department; Electronics; Government; India; New Delhi; Computer Vision Laboratory; University; Maryland; College Park; University; Illinois; Urbana-Champaign; Donald Biggar Willet Professor; Department; Computer Engineering; Beckman Institute; Coordinated Science Laboratory; research; extraction; representation; structure; images; video; use; sources; scene representation; recognition; sensors; computer vision; applications; communication; image manipulation; information retrieval; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##true@@true$$
467434-2 0 13----Bio----#text.P.DIV.DIV.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	understand:1 center:1 open:1 wilei:1 sequenc:1 hewlett:1 recognit:2 kluwer:1 board:1 director:2 ieee:5 editori:1 system:1 transact:3 advanc:3 machineri:1 prize:1 emanuel:1 fellow:1 harvei:1 artifici:2 face:1 press:1 graphic:1 depart:1 structur:1 engin:4 issu:1 applic:1 coeditor:1 associ:6 american:2 electron:1 best:1 analysi:2 innov:1 institut:2 gestur:1 scienc:3 scholarship:1 receiv:2 young:1 technolog:4 research:1 beckman:1 process:1 pattern:4 mechan:1 intern:5 guest:1 scholar:1 illinoi:1 intellig:3 award:8 electr:1 iee:1 stewart:1 univers:3 ta:1 maryland:1 motion:1 select:1 int:1 frederick:1 imag:5 continu:1 nation:1 inform:2 co:2 machin:1 comput:3 distinguish:1 trevithick:1 alumnu:1 model:1 springer:1 paper:1 packard:1 dyer:1 journal:5 author:1 japan:1 hyderabad:1 societi:2 presidenti:1 serv:1 vision:3 mathemat:1 edit:1 achiev:1 merit:1 verlag:1 multimedia:1 book:2 investig:1 special:1 studi:1 optic:2 pior:1 found:1	||	He received the 1999 Emanuel R. Piore award of the IEEE, and the 1998 Technology Achievement Award of the International Society for Optical Engineering, and 2008 TA Stewart-Dyer/Frederick Harvey Trevithick Prize of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, and 2008 Open Innovation Research Award from Hewlett-Packard. He was selected as Associate for 1998-99 and 2006-07 and Beckman Associate for 1990-91 in the University of Illinois Center for Advanced Study. He received Distinguished Alumnus Award from University of Maryland Department of Computer Science (2008), Best Paper Award from IEEE Transaction on Multimedia (2006), University Scholar Award (1985), Presidential Young Investigator Award (1984), National Scholarship (1967-72), and President’s Merit Award (1966).  He has co-authored the books Pattern Models (Wiley, 1983), Motion and Structure from Image Sequences (Springer-Verlag, 1992), and Face and Gesture Recognition (Kluwer, 2001); and co-edited the book Advances in Image Understanding (IEEE Press, 1996). He is a fellow of IEEE, American Association for Artificial Intelligence, International Association for Pattern Recognition,Association for Computing Machinery, American Association for the Advancement of Science, and International Society for Optical Engineering. He is on the editorial boards of the journals IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence; Computer Vision, Graphics, and Image Processing; Journal of Mathematical Imaging and Vision; Journal of Pattern Analysis and Applications; Int. Journal of Imaging Systems and Technology; Journal of Information Science and Technology; and IEE Japan Transactions on Electrical and Electronic Engineering; and and a guest coeditor of the Artificial Intelligence Journal’s special issue on vision. He was the Founding Director of International Institute of Information Technology, Hyderabad where he continues to serve as Director International.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: International Society for Optical Engineering; Institution of Mechanical Engineers; Hewlett-Packard; University of Illinois Center for Advanced Study; University of Maryland Department of Computer Science; Kluwer; American Association for Artificial Intelligence; International Association for Pattern Recognition , Association for Computing Machinery; American Association; Advancement of Science; International Society for Optical Engineering; IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence; Computer Vision; Journal of Mathematical Imaging; Journal of Pattern Analysis; Journal of Imaging Systems and Technology ; Journal of Information Science and Technology; IEE Japan Transactions on Electrical and Electronic Engineering; Artificial Intelligence Journals; Founding Director of International Institute of Information Technology; 	PERSON: Emanuel R. Piore; Harvey Trevithick; Beckman; Wiley; 	DATE: 1999; 1998; 2008; 2008; 2008; 2006; 1985; 1984; 1966; 1983; 1992; 2001; 1996; 	LOCATION: Hyderabad; 	NOUN: Emanuel R. 75960-2 6 2----Presentation----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	good:1 kei:1 scheme:1 year:1 right:1 eavesdropp:1 codebreak:1 steganographi:1 content:1 digit:1 present:1 inform:1 transact:1 commun:2 todai:1 vari:1 secretli:1 model:1 identif:1 sought:1 signal:3 ingredi:1 jammer:1 transmiss:1 applic:1 network:1 hoc:1 authent:1 provabl:1 mai:1 mean:1 theoret:1 talk:1 abstract:1 includ:1 manag:1 track:1 us:1 problem:1 analyz:1 thousand:1 framework:2 human:1 multimedia:1 encount:1 ad:1 degrad:1 method:1 design:1	||	Abstract: For thousands of years, humans have sought means to secretly communicate. Today, ad hoc signaling methods are used in applications as varied as digital rights management for multimedia, content identification, authentication, steganography, transaction tracking, and networking. This talk will present an information-theoretic framework for analyzing such problems and designing provably good signaling schemes. Key ingredients of the framework include models for the signals being communicated and the degradations, jammers, eavesdroppers and codebreakers that may be encountered during transmission.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: thousands; years; humans; means; Today; ad; signaling methods; applications; rights management; multimedia; content identification; authentication; steganography; transaction tracking; networking; talk; framework; problems; signaling schemes; Key ingredients; framework; models; signals; degradations; jammers; eavesdroppers; codebreakers; transmission; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

75960-3 18 4----Bio----#text.P.BODY.HTML.#document	rijksuniversiteit:1 phd:1 lead:1 particular:1 scientist:1 patent:1 faculti:1 kei:1 prior:1 contribut:2 time:1 univers:1 interest:1 relat:1 hewlett:2 philip:1 interoper:1 cryptographi:1 founder:1 eindhoven:1 hold:2 signific:1 content:1 digit:2 inform:2 watermark:2 ieee:3 co:1 visual:1 transact:1 program:2 commun:2 distinguish:1 corpor:1 fellow:1 media:2 posit:1 committe:1 princip:1 forens:1 coral:1 vice:1 identif:1 signal:1 former:1 packard:2 activ:2 applic:1 biometr:1 kalker:4 real:1 area:1 drm:1 presid:1 associ:1 dece:1 ton:1 dr:3 member:1 netherland:1 held:1 technic:3 audio:2 standard:1 technologist:1 mathemat:1 variou:1 particip:1 huawei:2 technolog:2 research:2 acoust:1 field:1 leiden:1 process:2 chair:1 multimedia:1 secur:3 academ:1 led:1 laboratori:1 theori:1 group:1	||	Ton Kalker	##true@@false$$	is Vice President of Technology of Corporate Research at Huawei Technologies. He is a Fellow of IEEE for his contributions to applications of digital watermarking, and holds more than 40 patents. He is active in the IEEE and has held key leading technical positions in various standardization groups related to DRM interoperability, in particular Coral and DECE. He also actively participates in the academic community. He is a co-founder of the IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and is former Chair of the Associated Technical Committee. Prior to Huawei, Dr. Kalker was a Distinguished Technologist at Hewlett-Packard Laboratories, where he led R&D programs on real-time communication, acoustical audio processing and media security. Before Hewlett-Packard, Dr. Kalker was a Principal Scientist at Philips Research, where he made significant contributions to Philipsâ€™ Multimedia Security Program, in the area of digital watermarking and content identification. Dr. Kalker holds a Ph.D. in Mathematics from the Rijksuniversiteit Leiden, The Netherlands, and he has been a faculty member of the Technical University of Eindhoven. His interests are in the field of signal and audio-visual processing, media security, biometrics, information theory and cryptography.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Technology of Corporate Research; Huawei Technologies; DRM; DECE; IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics; Associated Technical Committee; Huawei; Hewlett-Packard Laboratories; Hewlett-Packard; Philips Research; Philips Multimedia Security Program; Technical University of Eindhoven; 	PERSON: Kalker; Dr. Kalker; Dr. Kalker; Dr. Kalker; 	LOCATION: Coral; Rijksuniversiteit Leiden; The Netherlands; 	NOUN: Ton Kalker; Vice President; Technology; Corporate Research; Huawei Technologies; Fellow; IEEE; contributions; applications; watermarking; patents; IEEE; positions; standardization groups; DRM interoperability; Coral; DECE; community; co-founder; IEEE Transactions; Information Forensics; Chair; Associated Technical Committee; Huawei; Dr. Kalker; Technologist; Hewlett-Packard Laboratories; R&D programs; communication; audio processing; media security; Hewlett-Packard; Dr. Kalker; Principal Scientist; Philips Research; contributions; Philips Multimedia Security Program; area; watermarking; content identification; Dr. Kalker; Ph.D.; Mathematics; Rijksuniversiteit Leiden; Netherlands; faculty member; Technical University; Eindhoven; interests; field; signal; processing; media security; biometrics; information theory; cryptography; 	||	##false@@true$$	||	##false@@true$$

75960-4 16 2----Research----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.FORM.BODY.HTML.#document	phd:2 illinoi:1 can:1 broad:1 data:1 engin:1 former:1 electr:1 amount:1 washington:1 jodi:1 pierr:1 hide:1 student:1 univers:2 graduat:1 st:1 limit:1 element:1 audio:1 optim:1 fundament:1 class:1 problem:1 us:1 game:1 print:1 inform:2 visual:1 hidden:1 reliabl:1 loui:1 determin:1 professor:1 commun:1 theori:1 media:1 moulin:1	||	Using elements of game, communication and optimization theories, Jody O'Sullivan, Ph.D., professor of electrical engineering at Washington University in St. Louis, and his former graduate student, Pierre Moulin, Ph.D., now at the University of Illinois, have determined the fundamental limits on the amount of information that can be reliably hidden in a broad class of data or information-hiding problems, whether they are in visual, audio or print media.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Washington University; University of Illinois; 	PERSON: Jody O'Sullivan; Pierre Moulin; 	LOCATION: St. Louis; 	NOUN: elements; game; communication; optimization theories; Jody O'Sullivan; Ph.D.; professor; engineering; Washington University; St. Louis; graduate student; Pierre Moulin; Ph.D.; University; Illinois; limits; amount; information; class; data; problems; print media; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##true@@false$$
75960-4 16 3----Research----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.FORM.BODY.HTML.#document	limit:1 work:1 constant:1 hundr:1 theorem:1 fundament:1 paramet:1 data:1 problem:1 abl:1 someth:1 els:1 inform:1 plug:1 hide:2 basic:1 predict:1 determin:1 emb:1 theori:2 year:1 try:1	||	"This is the fundamental theorem of data hiding," O'Sullivan said.  "One hundred years from now, if someone's trying to embed information in something else, they'll never be able to hide more than is determined by our theory.  This is a constant.  You basically plug in the parameters of the problem you are working and the theory predicts the limits."	##false@@false$$		||	PERSON: O'Sullivan; 	NOUN: theorem; data hiding; O'Sullivan; years; someone; information; something; theory; parameters; problem; theory; limits; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##false@@true$$
75960-4 13 1----Research----#text.P.SPAN.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	need:1 servic:1 perform:1 hide:1 interest:1 spars:1 video:1 work:1 class:1 involv:1 imag:2 digit:1 compress:1 inform:2 appli:1 aim:1 restor:1 professor:1 comput:1 novel:1 result:1 model:1 scope:1 common:1 broaden:1 signal:4 recent:1 applic:2 authent:1 current:1 develop:1 videoconferenc:1 theoret:1 find:1 includ:1 optim:2 fundament:1 ideal:1 problem:2 research:1 represent:1 techniqu:1 process:3 narrow:1 multimedia:1 focu:1 appropri:1 tv:1 method:2 measur:1 somewhat:1	||	Professor Moulin's research involves the development of novel methods for modeling and processing signals, images, and video, with a focus on problems of compression, restoration, and, more recently, information hiding and authentication. Applications of interest include videoconferencing, digital TV, multimedia services, and computed imaging. A problem that is fundamental and common to those applications is the need to find sparse signal representations and processing techniques that optimize appropriate performance measures. The work aims to broaden the scope of information-theoretic methods and results on optimal signal processing that currently apply to somewhat narrow classes of idealized signals.	##false@@false$$		||	PERSON: Moulin; 	NOUN: Professor Moulin; research; development; methods; modeling; processing signals; images; video; focus; problems; compression; restoration; information hiding; authentication; Applications; interest; videoconferencing; TV; multimedia services; imaging; problem; applications; need; signal representations; processing techniques; performance measures; work; scope; methods; signal processing; classes; signals; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##false@@true$$
75960-4 13 2----Research----#text.P.SPAN.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	complex:1 model:1 promis:1 block:1 radar:1 signal:2 adapt:1 cowork:1 wavelet:1 prof:1 cover:1 estim:3 altern:1 bayesian:1 quantiz:1 relat:1 nonorthogon:1 bank:1 effici:1 develop:2 motion:2 dens:1 video:2 work:2 includ:1 standard:1 optim:1 regular:1 multiresolut:1 involv:1 code:2 imag:6 togeth:1 statist:2 much:1 techniqu:6 process:1 field:1 compress:1 appli:1 densiti:1 restor:2 base:1 design:1 filter:1 spectral:1	||	Much of Prof. Moulin's work involves wavelets and related multiresolution techniques, including designs adapted to signal statistics. In image compression, he has developed optimal quantization techniques for nonorthogonal filter banks and applied these techniques to image and video coding. Together with his coworkers, he has also developed efficient techniques for modeling, estimation, and coding of dense video motion fields. The techniques are a promising alternative to the standard block-based motion estimation techniques. His work in statistical signal and image processing covers spectral density estimation, radar imaging, complexity-regularized image restoration, and Bayesian image restoration.	##false@@false$$		||	PERSON: Moulin; 	NOUN: Prof. Moulin; work; wavelets; techniques; designs; statistics; image compression; quantization techniques; filter banks; techniques; image; video coding; coworkers; techniques; modeling; estimation; coding; video motion fields; techniques; alternative; motion estimation techniques; work; signal; image processing; density estimation; radar imaging; image restoration; image restoration; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##false@@true$$

75960-4 17 6----Presentation----#text.P.SPAN.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	model:3 can:1 gener:1 data:3 payload:2 perform:1 show:1 recent:2 algorithm:1 tutori:1 fit:1 estim:1 hide:3 side:1 abstract:1 detect:1 fundament:1 effort:1 describ:2 problem:4 game:1 code:1 sever:1 techniqu:1 present:2 inform:2 watermark:3 overview:1 larg:1 popular:1 base:1 commun:1 approach:1 theori:4 low:1 channel:1 design:1 review:1	||	Abstract:	##true@@false$$	In this tutorial we will present some recent approaches to modeling watermarking and data hiding as communication problems. We first overview the data hiding problem (large payload) and show how one can model it as a channel coding problem with side information. We further describe how several popular data-hiding techniques fit into this model and describe their performance. We also review the watermarking problem (low payload) and present recent efforts to design watermarking algorithms based on fundamentals of detection theory, estimation theory, game theory, and information theory in general.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: tutorial; approaches; modeling watermarking; data hiding; communication problems; overview; data hiding problem; payload; channel; problem; side information; techniques; model; performance; watermarking problem; payload; efforts; algorithms; fundamentals; detection theory; estimation theory; game theory; information theory; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
