On a consultancy basis for large institutions for the implementation of processes and methodologies, I have actively participated to the definition, development and implementation of industrialization methods and techniques for the development and the maintenance of the applications, based on existing standard methodologies such as Prince2 and PMI, implying to reach and maintain the CMMI level 3 as well as ITIL and ISO 9001 certifications.  Other consultancy work for different customers consisted in helping them define the relationship between the Business, the Infrastructure and the Development Departments, which has led to precise SLA’s definition.  Author of an IBM book “Information Technology : A Strategic Outlook for the Insurance Industry”, available in English, French and Japanese. After working as a Research Scientist for Bell Communications Research in Morristown, New Jersey, he joined the University of Illinois as Assistant Professor (1996) and later became Associate Professor (1999) and Professor (2003) in the Department of	##false@@false$$	Electrical and Computer Engineering	##false@@true$$	, Research Professor in the	##false@@false$$	Coordinated Science Laboratory	##false@@true$$	, faculty member in the	##false@@false$$	Beckman Institute	##false@@true$$	's	##false@@false$$	Image Formation and Processing Group	##false@@true$$	, and affiliate professor in the department of	##false@@false$$	Statistics	##false@@true$$	. He is also a member of the	##false@@false$$	Information Trust Institute	##false@@true$$	and the founding director of the new	##false@@false$$	Center for Information Forensics	##false@@true$$	, a multidisciplinary research center currently involving twenty	##false@@false$$	colleagues	##false@@true$$	. His fields of professional interest are information theory, image and video processing, statistical signal processing and modeling, decision theory, information hiding and authentication, and the application of multiresolution signal analysis, optimization theory, and fast algorithms to these areas.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Ecole Polytechnique; Washington University; Bell Communications Research; University of Illinois; Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering; Coordinated Science Laboratory; Beckman Institute 's Image Formation and Processing Group; Information Trust Institute; Center for Information Forensics; 	PERSON: Pierre Moulin; 	DATE: 1990; 1996; 1999; 2003; 	LOCATION: Mons; Belgium; St. Louis; Morristown; New Jersey; 	NOUN: Pierre Moulin; Engineer degree; Ecole Polytechnique; Mons; Belgium; doctorate; Washington University; St. Louis; Research Scientist; Bell Communications Research; Morristown; New Jersey; University; Illinois; Assistant Professor; Associate Professor; Professor; Department; Computer Engineering; Research Professor; Coordinated Science Laboratory; faculty member; Beckman Institute; Image Formation; Processing Group; affiliate professor; department; Statistics; member; Information Trust Institute; director; Center; Information Forensics; research center; colleagues; fields; interest; information theory; image; video processing; signal processing; modeling; decision theory; information hiding; authentication; application; signal analysis; optimization theory; algorithms; areas; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##true@@false$$

He was a Guest Editor of the IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 2000 special issue on Information-Theoretic Imaging; Guest Editor of the IEEE Transactions on Signal Processing's 2003 special issue on Data Hiding; and member of the IEEE Image and Multidimensional Signal Processing (IMDSP) Society Technical Committee (1998-2003) and the Board of Governors of the IEEE Signal Processing Society (2005-2007). He is co-founder and Editor-in-Chief of the new	##false@@false$$	IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security	##false@@true$$	. He is a Fellow of IEEE (2003), recipient of a 1997 Career award from the National Science Foundation, and of the IEEE Signal Processing Society 1997 Best Paper award in the IMDSP area. He is also co-author (with Juan Liu) of a paper that received the IEEE Signal Processing Society 2002 Young Author Best Paper award  in the IMDSP area. He was selected as Beckman Associate of UIUC's Center for Advanced Study (2003) and Sony Faculty Scholar (2005-2007). He was on the Dean's list of teachers rated excellent by their students in 1996, 1999, 2000, 2005, and 2007.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Society Technical Committee; Board of Governors; Information Forensics and Security; National Science Foundation; Young Author Best Paper; UIUC; Sony; 	PERSON: Juan Liu; Beckman; 	DATE: 1996; 1998; 1999; 2002; 2002; 2006; 1999; 2000; 2003; 2003; 1997; 1997; 2002; 2003; 1996; 1999; 2000; 2005; 2007; 	NOUN: Associate Editor; IEEE Transactions; Information Theory; IEEE Transactions; Image Processing; Area Editor; co-chair; IEEE Information Theory workshop; Detection; Estimation; Classification; Guest Editor; IEEE Transactions; Information Theory; issue; Imaging; Guest Editor; IEEE Transactions; Signal Processing; issue; Data; member; IEEE Image; Signal Processing; IMDSP; Society Technical Committee; Board; Governors; IEEE Signal Processing Society; co-founder; Editor-in-Chief; IEEE Transactions; Information Forensics; Security; Fellow; IEEE; Career award; National Science Foundation; IEEE Signal Processing Society; Paper award; IMDSP area; co-author; Juan Liu; paper; IEEE Signal Processing Society; Young Author Best Paper award; IMDSP area; Beckman Associate; UIUC; Center; Advanced Study; Sony Faculty Scholar; Dean; list; teachers; students; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@true$$

75960-3 0 12----Research----#text.B.P.BODY.HTML.#document	detect:1 model:1 optim:1 hash:1 multiresolut:1 recognit:1 signal:1 imag:1 statist:1 wavelet:1 steganographi:1 kei:1 process:2 compress:1 stochast:1 fingerprint:1 inform:2 watermark:1 estim:1 secur:1 pattern:1 word:1 theori:1 analysi:1	||	KEY WORDS: Signal processing, modeling, compression, imaging, information theory, statistics, stochastic processes, wavelets and multiresolution analysis, estimation, detection, pattern recognition, watermarking, hashing, fingerprinting, steganography, information security, optimization.	##true@@false$$		||	NOUN: WORDS; Signal processing; modeling; compression; imaging; information theory; statistics; processes; wavelets; analysis; estimation; detection; pattern recognition; watermarking; fingerprinting; steganography; information security; optimization; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
75960-3 0 13----Research----#text.P.BODY.HTML.#document	understand:1 simpl:1 gener:1 infer:1 challeng:1 student:1 varieti:1 role:1 central:1 video:1 select:1 principl:2 lack:1 imag:2 statist:3 solv:1 compress:1 inform:3 emerg:1 restor:1 underli:1 moulin:1 forens:1 model:1 engin:1 identifi:1 signal:1 brought:1 recent:1 applic:2 algorithm:1 area:1 develop:1 bear:1 detect:1 includ:1 fundament:2 speak:1 problem:4 research:1 main:1 process:1 secur:1 focu:1 eleg:1 plai:1 approach:1 theori:2 method:1	||	Moulin and his students research the application of statistics and information theory to a variety of engineering problems. Generally speaking, the main challenge is to select emerging problems for which a fundamental understanding is still lacking, identify the underlying simple and elegant principles that should be brought to bear on such problems, and develop methods and algorithms for solving them. Statistical modeling and fundamental principles of statistical inference and information theory play a central role in this approach.  The application areas include imaging and signal, image and video processing, with focus on problems of compression, restoration, detection, and more recently, information forensics and security.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: Moulin; students; application; statistics; information theory; variety; engineering problems; challenge; problems; understanding; principles; problems; methods; algorithms; modeling; principles; inference; information theory; role; approach; application areas; imaging; signal; image; video processing; focus; problems; compression; restoration; detection; information forensics; security; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
75960-3 0 14----Research----#text.P.BODY.HTML.#document	perform:1 radar:1 wavelet:2 estim:2 bayesian:1 spars:1 nonorthogon:1 bank:2 motion:1 video:1 work:1 class:1 code:1 imag:3 statist:1 inform:1 appli:1 aim:1 restor:2 filter:2 spectral:1 result:1 complex:1 model:1 scope:1 broaden:1 line:1 signal:4 adapt:1 quantiz:1 current:1 dens:1 theoret:1 find:1 thrust:1 includ:2 optim:4 regular:1 ideal:1 research:2 represent:1 techniqu:2 process:2 field:1 eg:1 narrow:1 appropri:1 densiti:1 base:1 exampl:1 method:1 measur:1 somewhat:1 design:1	||	One of our research thrusts includes finding sparse signal representations (e.g., wavelet-based) and processing techniques that optimize appropriate performance measures. This line of research aims at broadening the scope of information-theoretic methods and results on optimal signal processing, which currently apply to somewhat narrow classes of idealized signals. Examples of this work include design of wavelets and filter banks optimally adapted to signal statistics; optimal quantization techniques for nonorthogonal filter banks; modeling, estimation and coding of dense video motion fields; spectral density estimation, radar imaging, complexity-regularized image restoration, and Bayesian image restoration.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: research thrusts; signal representations; processing techniques; performance measures; line; research; scope; methods; signal processing; classes; signals; Examples; work; design; wavelets; filter banks; statistics; quantization techniques; filter banks; modeling; estimation; coding; video motion fields; density estimation; radar imaging; image restoration; image restoration; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
75960-3 0 15----Research----#text.P.BODY.HTML.#document	formerli:1 steganograph:1 medard:1 perform:1 nois:1 arbitrari:1 washington:1 munich:1 hide:2 interest:1 work:2 joint:1 flaw:2 ralf:1 hash:1 muriel:1 avail:1 resist:1 code:2 togeth:2 content:1 digit:1 inform:4 watermark:3 system:3 emerg:1 commun:1 forens:1 desynchron:1 can:2 remedi:1 data:2 protect:1 date:1 applic:1 prof:3 fingerprint:1 jodi:1 area:1 analysi:2 develop:2 theoret:1 find:1 heurist:1 thrust:1 robust:1 includ:1 previous:1 fundament:1 mit:1 research:1 nowadai:1 main:1 uiuc:1 achiev:1 secur:4 tu:1 exampl:1 approach:1 theori:3 method:4 koetter:1 attack:1 sullivan:1 bound:2	||	Our main research thrust nowadays is in the emerging area of information forensics and security.  Moulin's interest in information security dates  back from 1997, when he developed an information theory of watermarking and data hiding, together with Prof. Jody O' Sullivan (Washington U.). This theory finds applications to content protection; previously, only heuristic methods were available.  Since 2000, we have been developing a coding theory for data hiding, together with Prof. Ralf Koetter (formerly UIUC, now TU Munich). Examples of this work include fundamental performance bounds for watermarking, digital fingerprinting, and steganographic systems; codes that can achieve (or approach) these bounds; methods that resist arbitrary noise and desynchronization attacks; robust hashing methods; analysis of security flaws for watermarking systems; methods that can remedy those flaws; and information-theoretic analysis of secure communication systems (joint work with Prof. Muriel Medard, MIT).	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: UIUC; TU Munich; MIT; 	PERSON: Jody O ' Sullivan; Ralf Koetter; Muriel Medard; 	DATE: 1997; 2000; 	LOCATION: Washington U.; 	NOUN: research thrust; area; information forensics; security; Moulin; interest; information security dates; information theory; watermarking; data hiding; Prof. Jody O; Sullivan; Washington U.; theory; applications; protection; heuristic methods; theory; data hiding; Prof. Ralf Koetter; UIUC; TU Munich; Examples; work; performance bounds; watermarking; fingerprinting; systems; codes; approach; bounds; methods; noise; desynchronization attacks; methods; analysis; security flaws; systems; methods; flaws; analysis; communication systems; work; Prof. Muriel Medard; MIT; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@true$$

75960-0 7 6----Presentation----#text.P.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	model:3 can:1 gener:1 data:3 payload:2 perform:1 show:1 recent:2 algorithm:1 tutori:1 fit:1 estim:1 hide:3 side:1 abstract:1 detect:1 fundament:1 effort:1 describ:2 problem:4 game:1 code:1 sever:1 techniqu:1 present:2 inform:2 watermark:3 overview:1 larg:1 popular:1 base:1 commun:1 approach:1 theori:4 low:1 channel:1 design:1 review:1	||	Abstract:	##true@@false$$	In this tutorial we will present some recent approaches to modeling watermarking and data hiding as communication problems. We first overview the data hiding problem (large payload) and show how one can model it as a channel coding problem with side information. We further describe how several popular data-hiding techniques fit into this model and describe their performance. We also review the watermarking problem (low payload) and present recent efforts to design watermarking algorithms based on fundamentals of detection theory, estimation theory, game theory, and information theory in general.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: tutorial; approaches; modeling watermarking; data hiding; communication problems; overview; data hiding problem; payload; channel; problem; side information; techniques; model; performance; watermarking problem; payload; efforts; algorithms; fundamentals; detection theory; estimation theory; game theory; information theory; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

693093-2 5 2----Presentation----#text.P.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.BODY.HTML.#document	scale:1 model:1 can:2 maintain:1 natur:1 therebi:1 deploy:1 scalabl:1 network:4 must:2 intermedi:1 kei:1 mai:1 observ:1 graph:3 decentr:1 order:1 path:2 analysi:1 widespread:1 follow:1 peer:2 limit:1 platform:1 anonym:2 creat:1 origin:1 learn:1 us:1 technolog:1 restrict:1 topolog:1 inform:1 node:2 simul:1 larg:1 base:1 commun:4 due:1 within:1 construct:1 view:1 studi:1	||	Peer-to-peer networks, due to their decentralized construction, are a natural platform for anonymous communication and large-scale p2p networks may be the key to widespread deployment of anonymous communications technologies. In order to be scalable, however, p2p networks must maintain a limited view of the network, thereby creating a restricted topology graph of nodes that can communicate with each other. As all communication must follow paths within the graph, we study the information that can be learned about the origin of a path based on observing intermediate nodes. We use both graph models and simulations in our analysis.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: networks; construction; platform; communication; p2p networks; key; deployment; communications technologies; order; p2p networks; view; network; topology graph; nodes; communication; paths; graph; information; origin; path; nodes; graph models; simulations; analysis; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
693093-2 5 3----Presentation----#text.P.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.BODY.HTML.#document	unstructur:2 model:1 moder:1 connect:1 can:3 detriment:1 structur:1 subject:1 show:1 carri:1 network:4 contrast:1 arbitrari:1 graph:1 path:1 on:1 power:1 develop:1 follow:1 work:1 law:1 anonym:1 mathemat:1 global:1 poor:1 number:2 without:1 mix:1 topolog:4 degre:1 point:1 node:2 effect:1 remain:1 start:1 compromis:1 larg:1 often:1 target:1 emerg:1 view:1 attack:2 correl:1 hop:1 found:1	||	In our work, we contrast structured networks, where the topology of the graph follows a mathematical model, and unstructured ones, where arbitrary connections can be made. Unstructured networks often develop an emergent power-law topology; we have found that such topologies are a detriment for anonymity because they have poor mixing (paths remaining correlated to their starting point after a large number of hops) and because the high-degree nodes can be subject to a targeted attack. We show that effective attacks against such networks can be carried out with only a moderate number of compromised nodes and without a global view of the network topology.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: work; networks; topology; graph; model; ones; connections; networks; power-law topology; topologies; detriment; anonymity; paths; point; number; nodes; attack; attacks; networks; number; nodes; view; network topology; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
693093-2 5 4----Presentation----#text.P.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.BODY.HTML.#document	can:1 structur:1 accept:1 tend:1 good:2 show:1 therefor:1 approxim:1 network:5 de:2 hand:1 full:1 bruijn:2 optim:1 anonym:3 worst:1 ideal:1 shown:1 candid:1 us:1 averag:1 provid:1 mix:2 sever:1 achiev:1 topolog:1 system:1 attack:1 known:1 case:1 properti:1 studi:1	||	Structured networks, on the other hand, tend to have good mixing properties, and de Bruijn networks can be shown to achieve optimal mixing and therefore make an ideal candidate for anonymous p2p networks. We study the approximations to de Bruijn networks used in several p2p systems and show that they provide good anonymity on average, and acceptable anonymity in the worst case, even when the full topology of the network is known to the attackers.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: networks; hand; properties; Bruijn networks; candidate; p2p networks; approximations; networks; p2p systems; anonymity; average; anonymity; case; topology; network; attackers; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

402758-0 10 15----Research----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	negoti:2 administ:1 allow:1 can:1 data:1 foundat:1 inapplic:1 authent:1 open:3 resourc:1 area:1 requir:1 ident:2 decentr:1 semant:1 name:1 nimbl:1 autom:1 develop:2 central:1 work:1 control:3 firm:1 trust:2 environ:2 particip:1 us:2 meaning:1 access:3 provid:1 goal:1 tradit:1 flexibl:1 trustbuild:1 project:1 system:4 secur:1 entiti:1 outsid:2 base:1 approach:4 comput:2 theori:1 underli:1	||	In the area of data security, she is participating in the TrustBuilder project to develop automated trust negotiation, a new approach to access control and authentication for use in open computing environments. Such environments require nimble, flexible approaches to access control, so that entities from outside the open system can be allowed to make use of system resources. The traditional approach to access control in decentralized systems, namely, centrally administered, identity-based approaches, are inapplicable to open computing, as outsiders have no identity that is meaningful to the system. The goal of this work is to develop the underlying theory of trust negotiation, to provide a firm semantic foundation.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: area; data security; TrustBuilder project; trust negotiation; approach; access control; authentication; use; computing environments; environments; approaches; access control; entities; system; use; system resources; approach; access control; systems; approaches; computing; outsiders; identity; system; goal; work; theory; trust negotiation; firm; foundation; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

402758-0 17 13----Presentation----#text.P.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.DIV.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.BODY.HTML.#document	societ:1 birth:1 govern:1 integr:1 reason:1 abil:1 becom:1 requir:1 busi:1 power:1 inaccur:1 dead:1 famou:1 elect:1 evid:1 compani:1 vote:1 behind:1 class:1 cost:1 without:1 goal:1 content:1 statement:1 record:4 peopl:1 often:1 determin:1 addressesr:1 leav:1 can:1 inappropri:1 paper:1 date:1 ensur:1 gymnast:1 retent:1 easi:1 electron:3 major:1 sarban:1 law:1 uncertain:1 detect:1 perhap:1 trust:1 regul:1 us:2 problem:1 alter:1 term:1 replac:1 oxlei:1 insid:1 chang:2 act:1 financi:1 world:1	||	Inaccurate financial statements from major companies, dead people who still vote in elections, world-class gymnasts with uncertain birth dates: insiders often have the power and ability to make inappropriate changes to the content of electronic records.  As electronic records replace paper records, it becomes easy to make such alterations without leaving behind evidence that can be used to detect the changes and determine who made them.  The US Sarbanes-Oxley Act is perhaps the most (in)famous law that addressesre these problems, but it is just one of many regulations that require long-term high-integrity retention of electronic records, all with the goal of ensuring that societal trust in business and government at reasonable cost. 	##false@@false$$		||	LOCATION: US; 	NOUN: statements; companies; people; elections; gymnasts; birth dates; insiders; power; ability; changes; content; records; records; paper records; alterations; evidence; changes; US Sarbanes-Oxley Act; law; problems; regulations; retention; records; goal; trust; business; government; cost; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
402758-0 17 14----Presentation----#text.P.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.DIV.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.BODY.HTML.#document	progress:1 need:1 tamper:1 govern:1 can:1 give:1 proof:1 challeng:2 date:1 industri:1 open:1 pose:1 area:1 retent:1 respond:1 current:1 role:1 major:1 talk:1 technic:1 describ:2 problem:1 offer:1 research:3 product:1 record:1 secur:1 overview:1 address:1 discuss:1 plai:1 weak:2	||	In this talk, we will discuss some of the technical challenges posed by the need for "tamper-proof" retention of records.  We will describe how industry has responded to these challenges, the security weaknesses in current product offerings, and the role that researchers and government can play in addressing these weaknesses.  We will give an overview of research progress to date and describe the major open research problems in this area.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: talk; challenges; need; retention; records; industry; challenges; security weaknesses; product offerings; role; researchers; government; weaknesses; overview; research progress; date; research problems; area; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

402758-0 17 18----Bio----#text.DIV.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.DIV.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.BODY.HTML.#document	phd:1 illinoi:1 award:3 vulner:1 foundat:1 stanford:1 sss:1 univers:2 recipi:1 vldb:1 complianc:1 usenix:1 board:1 nation:1 databas:1 inform:1 editori:1 system:2 ieee:1 transact:4 professor:1 comput:1 fellow:1 vice:1 depart:1 regulatori:1 paper:2 knowledg:1 data:3 engin:1 former:1 journal:1 sigmod:1 extens:1 browser:1 presidenti:1 best:2 serv:1 scienc:2 winslett:1 detect:1 acm:5 manag:1 us:1 web:1 receiv:1 analyz:1 mariann:1 young:1 research:2 chair:1 secur:3 larg:1 base:1 investig:1	||	Marianne Winslett has been a professor in the Department of Computer Science at the University of Illinois since 1987. She is an ACM Fellow and the recipient of a Presidential Young Investigator Award from the US National Science Foundation.  She is the former vice-chair of ACM SIGMOD and has served on the editorial boards of ACM Transactions on the Web, ACM Transactions on Database Systems, IEEE Transactions on Knowledge and Data Engineering, ACM Transactions on Information and Systems Security, and the Very Large Data Bases Journal.  She has received two best paper awards for research on managing regulatory compliance data (VLDB, SSS) and one best paper award for research on analyzing browser extensions to detect security vulnerabilities (Usenix Security).  Her PhD is from Stanford University.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Department of Computer Science; University of Illinois; US National Science Foundation; ACM Transactions on Database Systems; Data Engineering; ACM Transactions on Information and Systems Security; Very Large Data Bases Journal; SSS; Stanford University; 	PERSON: Marianne Winslett; 	DATE: 1987; 	NOUN: Marianne Winslett; professor; Department; Computer Science; University; Illinois; ACM Fellow; Presidential Young Investigator Award; US National Science Foundation; vice-chair; ACM SIGMOD; editorial boards; ACM Transactions; Web; ACM Transactions; Database Systems; IEEE Transactions; Knowledge; Data Engineering; ACM Transactions; Information; Systems Security; Data Bases Journal; paper awards; research; compliance data; VLDB; SSS; paper award; research; browser extensions; security vulnerabilities; Usenix Security; PhD; Stanford University; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##true@@false$$
